## Document_1

Carrier aggregation (CA) can drop from a maximum of 5 bands to just 2 bands on Peplink hardware, such as the MAX BR1 5G Pro and MAX BR2 5G Pro, after approximately an hour of use. This behavior has been observed across multiple carriers including Verizon, AT&T, and T-Mobile, and occurs regardless of whether the CA bands are set to Auto or manually selected. The drop in CA may be influenced by factors such as limitations of the Sierra Wireless modem or Peplink firmware, or external factors related to tower transmission. Stress tests indicate that once the CA drops to 2 bands, it does not increase beyond that level during repeated use.

## Document_2

The Peplink MAX BR1 Pro 5G has been certified for compatibility with AT&T's FirstNet service.

## Document_3

The IMEI number for the Pepwave Max BR1 mini LTEA can be found through InControl2 by clicking on details under the cellular section, as well as directly in the web admin interface under the cellular details on the main page.

## Document_4

To find the IMEI number for the Pepwave Max BR1 Mini LTE-US-T, it can be located on the white sticker inside the original packaging box. Alternatively, the IMEI number can be accessed by logging into the router and navigating to the Cellular Details tab.

## Document_5

The Pepwave MAX Transit Duo requires a high current supply of 2.4 Amps to operate properly on USB power. If using multiple lower current supplies, it is important to utilize both USB connectors to meet the necessary power requirements.

## Document_6

To activate a SIM card for a new BR1 MAX MK2, the IMEI number can be found on the device's box or obtained from the Peplink Partner from whom the device was purchased, as Peplink provides a method for Partners to look up the IMEI by serial number.

## Document_7

An expired warranty on an AP managed by InControl 2 (IC2) does not affect the ability to push configurations to the AP. Users can purchase IC2 subscriptions even after the warranty period has ended to maintain management capabilities.

## Document_8

When using a 24 port switch with two power supplies, it is possible to connect each power supply to a separate UPS battery backup. However, the power usage will not be sequential; instead, it will be load shared, meaning both UPS power sources will be utilized simultaneously rather than one after the other.

## Document_9

To successfully delete a VLAN network that is showing as 'Used by', it is important to check if the VLAN is set as a named VLAN on a specific physical port. Additionally, verify if a SpeedFusion Layer 2 profile is utilizing the VLAN, as this could prevent deletion.

## Document_10

The Peplink Balance 210 supports up to 10,000 concurrent NAT sessions. For detailed specifications, it is advisable to contact a local Peplink partner.

## Document_11

For the Pepwave Max BR1 Mini HW3 variant, a compatible adapter plug for the 4-pin DC power block can be found from Cradlepoint, specifically model 170665-000, which is readily available.

## Document_12

The new Pepwave Max BR1 Mini HW3 variant uses a 4 pin DC power block with a center pin positive configuration for the DC barrel. An adapter plug compatible with this configuration can be found on Amazon, as suggested in the conversation.

## Document_13

To manage access to different SSIDs on a Pepwave Max BR1 5G, you can define a schedule and set that schedule per SSID, allowing you to turn off the personal AP during work hours when the connection is less than ideal.

## Document_14

To connect a Pepwave MAX BR1 Mini Cat 7 to a DC barrel connector, it is advisable to use an adapter rather than cutting or replacing the barrel connector. The power pin-outs for the Molex 4-pin adapter can be found in the user manual, which specifies which pins correspond to DC+ and DC- wires.

## Document_15

The Winegard 360+ antenna system is not suitable for use with the Pepwave Max BR1 Pro 5G due to its insufficient number of antenna elements and its design primarily for 4G/LTE frequencies. It is recommended to use a dedicated 5G antenna, such as the Peplink 42G antenna, which is 5G ready and includes GPS and WiFi capabilities for accessing public WiFi networks.

## Document_16

When attempting to access the login page of a Peplink Max BR1 MK2 router at 192.168.50.1, it is important to verify the IP address assigned to the device connected to the LAN. If the IP address is in the range of 192.168.50.x, users should also check if the HTTPS protocol is required by trying https://192.168.50.1.

## Document_17

To access the login page of a Peplink Max BR1 MK2, if the standard IP address 192.168.50.1 does not respond, it may be necessary to use the reset button located in a small hole on the device to restore functionality.

## Document_18

The Pepwave MAX BR1 router has a default IP address of 192.168.50.1 and uses DHCP to assign IP addresses to connected clients starting from 192.168.50.10. If the SAT TV device is using DHCP, it will receive a new IP address within the 192.168.50.10-100 range. If the SAT TV does not use DHCP, the BR1's network settings can be changed to use the 192.168.1.0/24 network instead of the default 192.168.50.0/24. An advanced IP scanner can be used to identify devices on the network.

## Document_19

If a connection is refused when trying to access a PepLink Max BR1 router at the IP address 192.168.25.1, it is important to verify that the default IP has been changed from 192.168.50.1 to 192.168.25.1. Additionally, checking the IP address of the connected laptop or PC is crucial to ensure it is on the same subnet as the router for successful connectivity.

## Document_20

The Pepwave MAX BR1 Pro does not support converting the WAN port to a LAN port, which means it cannot be configured to provide additional LAN ports beyond the default number available.

## Document_21

In IP passthrough mode, the Pepwave MAX BR1 will retain its default management IP address of 192.168.50.1, but it will not have an IP scheme for routing. To access the BR1 for management, a PC must be assigned a static IP address within the 192.168.50.x subnet. The Linksys router can use its default subnet for DHCP settings to facilitate communication between the devices.

## Document_22

For the MAX HD2 LTE IP67, the power connector part number is ACW-636. Additionally, the PoE injector for this device has a different part number, which is ACW-107.

## Document_23

The default IP address for configuring the Pepwave MAX BR1 router is 192.168.50.1. To access the configuration page wirelessly, one must connect to the built-in access point (AP) of the BR1.

## Document_24

For configuring multiple Pepwave Max BR1 devices, the InControl2 cloud management platform can be used to store configurations in the cloud and push them to all devices, facilitating pre-staging of configurations.

## Document_25

To add users in InControl2, once a person is added, they will receive an email with a unique link. If the email is not received, the user can go to the InControl2 login page and select the 'Reset' option next to 'Forgot your password?' to receive a password reset email by entering their email address and clicking the Send button.

## Document_26

To unregister a router from an InControl2 account, one should remove the device from its current group within the existing organization. After this, the router can be added to a new organization or account.

## Document_27

Currently, InControl 2 (IC2) requires devices to be under warranty for management. If a device goes out of warranty, users must either renew the warranty or purchase an IC2 subscription to continue utilizing the management features. The subscription is considered affordable given the extensive capabilities that IC2 offers.

## Document_28

Carrier aggregation (CA) performance can vary based on the carrier's implementation rather than the limitations of the Peplink hardware or Sierra Wireless modem. In the USA, major carriers like Verizon, AT&T, and T-Mobile manage CA differently, which can affect the number of bands utilized. The user has observed that while they can achieve up to 5 band CA initially, it tends to drop to 2 bands after about an hour, impacting speeds. The user has not experienced CA dropping below 2 bands, and the response suggests that the carrier's management of CA may be influenced by network conditions and usage patterns.

## Document_29

The Peplink MAX BR1 5G Pro supports band 14, which is used by FirstNet, suggesting potential compatibility with the network. However, it is not explicitly listed on the FirstNet page, so confirmation from Peplink support may be necessary for definitive compatibility information.

## Document_30

The IMEI number for the Pepwave Max BR1 Mini LTE-US-T can be found in two locations: physically on a sticker on the bottom of the unit, where it is labeled after 'IMEA:' followed by a 15-digit number, and digitally through the device's GUI by navigating to Dashboard -> WAN Connection Status -> [name of your connection] -> Details, where it will be listed under 'WAN Connection Status.'

## Document_31

The Pepwave MAX Transit Duo may not operate correctly on 5V USB power if the USB cable is faulty or if the device requires more power due to the installation of two SIM cards and the creation of a tunnel. Insufficient voltage can cause the battery light to flash red every 10 seconds, indicating a power issue.

## Document_32

To activate a SIM card for a BR1 MAX MK2, the IMEI number can be found on the box rather than the device itself. If the admin password is not recognized after changing it, one option is to reset the router using a paperclip, which will allow logging back in. Alternatively, connecting a wired WAN cable and adding the device to InControl2 can bring it online.

## Document_33

Once the warranty of an access point (AP) managed by IC2 expires, new configurations cannot be pushed to the device from IC2. However, the expiration of the warranty does not impact the configurations that have already been applied to the device.

## Document_34

To connect a Pepwave MAX BR1 Mini Cat 7 to a pre-wired DC barrel connector in an Airstream, a specific adapter is required to convert the male barrel connector to a Molex 4-pin. The adapter can be purchased from a specified online retailer in the US.

## Document_35

To access the Sat TV interface after switching to a Max BR1 router, it may be necessary to adjust the IP address settings of the Max BR1 to match the existing network configuration, specifically ensuring it is within the same subnet as the Sat TV device, which is at 192.168.1.11. Additionally, if other devices such as an access point are not accessible, their IP addresses should also be checked to ensure they are correctly configured within the network.

## Document_36

If a connection is refused when trying to access a PepLink Max BR1 router at its IP address 192.168.25.1, one possible cause could be that the web admin port has been changed from the default port 80 to another port. This would result in an inability to connect using the standard URL format.

## Document_37

When attempting to connect to a PepLink Max BR1 router at the IP address 192.168.25.1, users may encounter a 'connection refused' error. Possible causes include incorrect network configuration, such as improper DNS settings or IP address conflicts. In this case, the main DNS was set to the router's IP, which could lead to issues. Additionally, while pinging the router from within the network shows some success, traceroute fails to return results, indicating potential routing issues. SSH connection attempts to port 22 also time out, suggesting that the SSH service may not be running or accessible on the router.

## Document_38

When attempting to connect to a PepLink Max BR1 router at the IP address 192.168.25.1, a connection refused error may occur. This could be due to issues with the router's configuration or network settings. The user is trying to ping the ISP allocated to the cellular modem on the BR1 and aims to remotely access a server on the LAN using SSH. It is noted that public IP addresses are being used on the cellular connection.

## Document_39

The IP address 192.168.25.1 is not accessible from the outside due to being in the 100.64.0.0/10 IP address block, which is used for carrier grade NAT. To access the router from an external network, one can obtain a static public IP address from the carrier or set up a PepVPN or IPSEC connection to a router that has a public IP address.

## Document_40

If a connection is refused when attempting to connect to a PepLink Max BR1 router at the IP address 192.168.25.1, one potential solution is to use the website http://whatsmyrouterip.com/ to help establish a connection through a web browser. This may assist in accessing the router's settings and performing a reset if necessary.

## Document_41

To successfully connect a Pepwave MAX BR1 in bridged mode to a Linksys WRT1900ACS v2 router, it is important to disable IP forwarding on the BR1. After making this change, reboot both devices to allow the Linksys router to obtain the cellular IP address from the BR1.

query: What troubleshooting steps and considerations should a technician take when experiencing a drop in carrier aggregation (CA) bands on a Peplink MAX BR1 5G Pro or BR2 5G Pro across multiple carriers, and what factors could be responsible for this behavior?
answer: When experiencing a drop in carrier aggregation (CA) bands from a maximum of 5 bands to just 2 on Peplink MAX BR1 5G Pro or BR2 5G Pro routers—even after about an hour of use and regardless of whether bands are set to Auto or manual selection—the technician should be aware that this is a known behavior observed across major US carriers (Verizon, AT&T, T-Mobile). Stress testing shows that once the CA drops to 2 bands, it does not increase again during the session. This reduction in CA is not necessarily due to Peplink firmware or Sierra Wireless modem limitations but may be primarily influenced by how the carrier manages CA in response to network conditions and usage patterns. The drop is not observed to go below 2 bands. Additionally, hardware like the MAX BR1 5G Pro supports relevant bands (e.g., band 14 for FirstNet), but for specific compatibility (such as FirstNet), confirmation with Peplink is advised. Technicians should consider both carrier-side management and hardware/firmware factors in their troubleshooting, but the most likely cause is carrier-specific CA management.

This CA band drop is observed across Verizon, AT&T, and T-Mobile, and may be influenced by the Sierra Wireless modem, Peplink firmware, or external tower factors.
Carrier aggregation performance is often determined by the carrier's own implementation; carriers in the USA manage CA differently, which can affect the number of bands utilized.
The user has not observed CA dropping below 2 bands, and carrier-side management of CA may be influenced by network conditions and usage patterns.
The Peplink MAX BR1 5G Pro supports band 14 (FirstNet), but explicit compatibility should be confirmed with Peplink support.

## Document_1

The maximum throughput for the Pepwave Surf SOHO T router is 120 Mbps, which explains why a speed test through the SOHO shows 95 Mbps, as it is operating within its specified limits. The difference in speed between the internet router and the SOHO is not indicative of a malfunction but rather a result of the router's maximum capacity.

## Document_2

The Pepwave Surf SOHO MK3 can successfully ping and trace the printer, indicating it is reachable on the network. However, the printer does not consistently appear on the client list and is unresponsive to Wake-on-LAN requests, which may suggest that the printer does not support this function. The client list may not accurately reflect all connected devices, especially if they are only communicating on the local area network without Internet access. Restarting the router temporarily allows the printer to appear on the client list, but it subsequently disappears after a few minutes, indicating potential connectivity issues.

## Document_3

The Pepwave Surf SOHO MK3 router is experiencing issues with a wired printer that intermittently appears on the client list but is marked as inactive. The printer can be pinged from a PC and is visible in traceroute results, but it does not respond to Wake-on-LAN requests and disappears from the client list after a few minutes. Wired PCs can print to the printer, but Wi-Fi devices, including a phone, cannot detect it. The printer lacks a web UI, and there are no VLANs configured on the network. The issue persists despite the router being powered by a UPS during a power outage, and it is suggested that pressing the router's reset button might resolve the issue.

## Document_4

The Pepwave Surf SOHO has a maximum throughput of 120 Mbps, which is typically measured under optimal lab conditions. Users may experience lower speeds in real-world scenarios, and if a user has upgraded their internet service to 200 Mbps but is only achieving speeds around 100 Mbps, it may be necessary to consider upgrading to a faster router to fully utilize the increased WAN speed.

## Document_5

The Peplink Surf SOHO has a maximum throughput of 120 Mbps, which may limit connection speeds to around 100 Mbps, even if the internet service is upgraded to 200 Mbps. For higher throughput needs, considering a Peplink Balance 20X or other devices that support closer to 200 Mbps is advisable.

## Document_6

The Pepwave Surf SOHO has a maximum throughput limit of 120 Mbps, which means it cannot achieve higher speeds regardless of the internet plan. For users needing higher speeds, upgrading to a more powerful unit such as the Balance One, which supports up to 600 Mbps, or the Balance 20X, which supports up to 900 Mbps, is recommended. These speeds are under optimal conditions, and actual speeds may vary based on factors like Wi-Fi signal strength and channel congestion.

## Document_7

The Pepwave Surf Soho MK3 Router is compatible with Spectrum, and it is advisable to minimize the hardware used from Spectrum for better performance. The Surf Soho MK3 is expected to come with the latest firmware version 8.1.1, but if it does not, the user has a downloaded version of firmware 7.1.2 that can be used for replacement. There are concerns regarding the firmware update practices of Spectrum, particularly with third-party modems like Netgear.

## Document_8

When considering extending wireless coverage with a Pepwave Surf SOHO MK3, it is confirmed that connecting two SOHOs over Ethernet to operate one as an access point (AP) is not feasible, as DHCP cannot be handled by the primary SOHO in that configuration. However, connecting an AP One Mini to the SOHO via Ethernet is possible, allowing both devices to be configured with the same SSIDs and passwords, enabling seamless connectivity for devices transitioning between the two based on signal strength.

## Document_9

The Pepwave SOHO router has a combined bandwidth limit of 120Mbps for both upload and download speeds. This means that users can expect speeds around 70Mbps down and 50Mbps up, which aligns with the observed performance during speed tests.

## Document_10

The Peplink Surf SOHO has a maximum throughput specification of 120 Mbps, which explains why the speed at the workstation via network cable is lower than the modem test speed of 350 Mbps. Users should refer to Peplink's website for detailed specifications regarding the device's performance limits.

## Document_11

The Surf SOHO router has a WAN port and LAN ports that support speeds of 1000Mbps; however, its throughput is limited to 100-120Mbps. This means that while the physical ports can handle high-speed connections, the router's processing capacity restricts the actual data transmission rate to a maximum of 120Mbps, which aligns with the specifications provided in the Surf SOHO spec sheet.

## Document_12

The Surf SOHO router supports Gigabit Ethernet on the LAN side, but it is limited to a maximum Internet connection speed of 100Mbps. This means that while the LAN ports can handle Gigabit speeds, the overall Internet throughput is capped at 100Mbps.

## Document_13

The throughput of a Pepwave Surf SOHO router can be influenced by several factors including the number of configured rules and the use of special features. Peplink tends to be conservative in their bandwidth specifications. WiFi performance can vary significantly due to factors such as frequency band, channel interference, signal strength, channel width, number of streams, and the WiFi generation of both the router and the client device.

## Document_14

The Pepwave Surf SOHO has a maximum throughput of 120 Mbps, which is significantly lower than the gigabit speeds available from fiber optic connections. Users may experience lower speeds on different connection types, such as 190 Mbps on a gigabit Ethernet USB dongle and 45 Mbps on 5GHz WiFi, indicating that the router's limitations are affecting overall performance.

## Document_15

The Pepwave Surf SOHO MK3 has a specified throughput capability of 120 Mbps. Users may experience lower speeds when connected through the router compared to a direct connection to the modem, which can be attributed to the router's limitations.

## Document_16

The Pepwave Surf SOHO MK3 may not be able to handle the upgraded internet speed of 400 Mbps, as indicated by the user's experience of only achieving 110 Mbps when connected through the router. Other models, such as the Balance One Core and three additional models, support throughput ranging from 350 to 600 Mbps, which may be more suitable for higher speed internet connections.

## Document_17

query: How does the Pepwave Surf SOHO MK3's throughput limitation affect users upgrading to high-speed internet plans (e.g., 200 Mbps or higher), and what alternative router models are recommended for users needing higher throughput?
answer: The Pepwave Surf SOHO MK3 router has a maximum WAN throughput of 120 Mbps, which is a hardware limitation. This means that even if a user upgrades their internet plan to 200 Mbps, 400 Mbps, or even 1 Gbps, the router will only deliver up to 120 Mbps to connected devices. Users may see actual speeds lower than this depending on real-world conditions and router load. The router's LAN and WAN ports support Gigabit Ethernet (1000 Mbps), but the routing throughput is capped by the device's processing capabilities, which leads to underutilization of higher-speed internet connections. For those needing to fully utilize higher-speed plans, upgrading to a more powerful router is necessary. Recommended alternatives include the Peplink Balance One (up to 600 Mbps), Peplink Balance 20X (up to 900 Mbps), and Balance One Core (350–600 Mbps), which are better suited for high-speed internet and larger user capacity.

## Document_1

To configure the GPIO interface on Peplink routers, users can refer to the Router API documentation available from Peplink. The documentation provides commands for querying the status of GPIO pins, although specific commands were not detailed in the conversation. Additionally, there is a possibility to query the power supply input voltage via the API, but further specifics were not provided in the response.

## Document_2

To reset the password on a Peplink device, smaller models typically have a reset button located in a hole that requires a paperclip to access. Larger models may feature an LCD with buttons for resetting.

## Document_3

The maximum MTU sizes supported on Peplink routers are as follows: Wired WAN has a maximum MTU of 1440 bytes, Cellular WAN has 1428 bytes, Mobile Internet supports 1492 bytes, and Wifi WAN has a maximum MTU of 1500 bytes.

## Document_4

The GPS route history for devices using the PepLink API is retained for a period of 1 year.

## Document_5

To change the master and slave roles in a 1+1 Backup High Availability pair without shutting down the master device, the following steps should be followed: First, log into the Master Device and uncheck 'Resume Master Role after Recovery' in the settings under high availability. Then, reboot the Master Device. Next, log into the previously Slave device, which will now assume the master role, and disable sync configuration. Set the preferred HA role as master. After that, log into the previously Master device, which will now be the slave, and set its preferred HA role as slave, entering the serial number of the new master device. Finally, reboot the slave device to complete the process.

## Document_6

The issue of a unit restarting multiple times may be related to changes made to outbound policy rules, particularly when switching the order of WAN connections, such as changing from WAN4 to WAN2. This problem reportedly began after upgrading to the latest firmware, suggesting a potential compatibility or stability issue with the new firmware when modifying outbound policies.

## Document_7

The ports in question are Micro USB ports, not USB-C, and are used solely for powering the device from a power brick during portable testing. These ports are wired only to the DC power bus and do not support data transmission, meaning they cannot be used to connect a Max Adapter or add another cellular modem.

## Document_8

Layer 2 VPN profiles can only include one VLAN or LAN segment on each device, meaning that a single profile cannot be shared across multiple VLANs.

## Document_9

To resolve the issue of a Pepwave device being registered to another organization in InControl, it is necessary to open a support ticket with Peplink. The support team will require a diagnostic report from the device and a picture showing the silver label as proof of ownership.

## Document_10

In the context of DHCP, the process involves DORA (Discover, Offer, Request, Acknowledge), where a client obtains an IP address. During the Discover and Request stages, clients send options to the DHCP server. The Peplink DHCP server will send all configured options during both the Offer and Acknowledge phases. A DHCP NACK (Negative Acknowledgment) is sent by the Peplink DHCP server only if it refuses to lease the requested IP address to the client.

## Document_11

On 24 May 2023, a maintenance fix was deployed to all InControl "planets" simultaneously, leading to an overload of the device communication cluster due to a high volume of incoming report data. This caused devices to initiate re-authentication, but the cluster was unable to process all requests in time, resulting in devices being incorrectly treated as offline. The system ceased requesting report data at 00:30, allowing the cluster load to decrease and re-authentication requests to be processed gradually. By 01:45, all devices were back online. To prevent future occurrences, fixes will be applied to only one planet at a time, additional resources have been added to the communications cluster, and the system will stop identifying devices as offline during high authentication volumes to avoid false alarms.

## Document_12

To delete an organization in InControl that was created with a personal email and is empty of devices, log in using that email, navigate to Organization Settings, and delete all devices on the device management page. The organization will be removed automatically after 28 days.

## Document_13

The InControl 2 Mars and Earth systems will undergo scheduled maintenance on November 14 and 28, 2022, at 00:30 GMT+0, lasting 60 minutes each, during which access to the system, Find My Peplink service, and captive portals may be less responsive or intermittently unavailable. The systems will be upgraded to version 2.12.0. The maintenance for the Earth system has been rescheduled to November 28 due to a potential performance issue identified in the release, and no maintenance was carried out on November 21.

## Document_14

The IC2 platform allows for tracking data usage by IMSI or ICCID per SIM card or across groups of SIMs when using Data pools from MVNOs. Partners have successfully built in-house systems utilizing the IC2 API to extract necessary data for monitoring and reporting purposes.

## Document_15

The InControl 2 Mars system will be upgraded to version 2.9.2 on September 27, 2021, at 00:30 GMT+0, with scheduled maintenance lasting 60 minutes. During this time, access to the system, Find My Peplink service, and captive portals may be less responsive or intermittently unavailable. The WAN quality reports in version 2.9.2 are noted to be easier to read, with improved chart intelligibility and hover functionality.

## Document_16

The InControl Mars and Mercury systems are undergoing scheduled maintenance on June 9, 2021, at 00:30 GMT+0, lasting 60 minutes. During this time, access to the systems and captive portals may be less responsive or intermittently unavailable. The upgrade will merge the Mercury system into Mars, with organizations on Mercury appearing on Mars after the upgrade.

## Document_17

InControl version 2.8.6 was deployed to the Mercury system, during which an issue with PepVPN configuration was identified. However, due to a configuration protection mechanism, no impact was made to any devices. The deployment to the Mars system has been postponed to September 8 at 00:30 GMT+0.

## Document_18

Currently, there is no report available that shows SIM ID, IMEI, and MDN together for data usage. However, there is a SIM data usage export tool under 'Sim Pool Reports' that is IMSI based. Additionally, SIM usage data can be accessed through Peplink's API services, which also operates on an IMSI basis, with endpoints available for hourly, daily, and monthly SIM usages.

## Document_19

Documentation and tutorials for InControl 2, including information on the Ads module and advertisement reports, can be found at the Ad Delivery Service Portal and the Ad Delivery Service Evaluation Guide. These resources provide insights into the capabilities of the Ads module and the types of reports available.

## Document_20

After scheduled maintenance on April 16 at 03:00 GMT+0, some Peplink and Pepwave client units were reported offline in IC2, affecting the Captive Portal functionality. Service was restored at 04:30 GMT+0.

## Document_21

To add users in InControl2, once a person is added, they will receive an email with a unique link. If the email is not received, the user can go to the InControl2 login page and select the 'Reset' option next to 'Forgot your password?' to receive a password reset email by entering their email address and clicking the Send button.

## Document_22

To set up email notifications for WAN connection status on a Peplink Balance, users can navigate to Group > Settings > Notifications to create multiple notification profiles for various purposes. This allows for more reliable notification management compared to using the CE device for sending alerts.

## Document_23

To move a device from one group to another within InControl, navigate to the Group Dashboard page, click on Manage, select the device by ticking the corresponding box, and then use the Actions pull-down menu to select Move.

## Document_24

Currently, InControl 2 (IC2) requires devices to be under warranty for management. If a device goes out of warranty, users must either renew the warranty or purchase an IC2 subscription to continue utilizing the management features. The subscription is considered affordable given the extensive capabilities that IC2 offers.

## Document_25

To query the status of a GPIO pin on Peplink routers, you can use the API endpoint 'https://192.168.50.1/api/status.gpio.input?list', which returns the status including voltage and type of the GPIO pin. For example, the response indicates the voltage level and whether the GPIO is enabled. This allows for monitoring the input voltage of the router.

## Document_26

To change the Master and Slave roles in a 1+1 Backup High Availability pair, the following steps should be followed: log into the Master device and uncheck 'Resume Master Role after Recovery' in the High Availability settings, then reboot the Master device. Next, log into the previously Slave device, disable configuration sync, set its preferred HA role to Master, and then log into the previously Master device to set its preferred HA role to Slave, entering the serial number of the new Master device. Finally, reboot the Slave device. This procedure allows for a successful role change without issues, provided both devices are connected to the same switch.

## Document_27

The Balance 710 HW1 experiences issues where it loses outbound WAN connection upon saving changes made to the unit. This problem occurs not only when changing outbound policies but also when modifications are made in the firewall section and inbound access services section. After applying changes, the unit may restart or fail to accept outbound/inbound WAN connections.

## Document_28

The Peplink BA310v2 experienced spontaneous restarts, which were suspected to be hardware related. After replacing the original power supply unit (PSU) with a different make and model, the reboot issues were resolved. When replacing a PSU, it is crucial to ensure that the voltage is identical, the polarity matches, and that the PSU can supply sufficient power to avoid damage or stability issues.

## Document_29

To inform DHCP clients that they are on a metered connection, one approach involves using DHCP option 43, which can be configured on Peplink routers. Additionally, Windows may utilize vendor extensions to convey network cost information through a specific packet format, where the cost level indicates the type of connection (e.g., unrestricted, fixed, variable) and cost flags provide details about usage conditions (e.g., over data limit, congested, roaming).

## Document_30

In Peplink routers, while it is possible to set various DHCP options, including option 43, there is no configuration option available to force the sending of option 43 in DHCP replies without it being specifically requested by the client. This behavior is noted as potentially necessary for clients to recognize a connection as metered, similar to how Android devices handle metered connections. However, testing indicates that simply setting option 43 does not achieve the desired outcome of clients automatically recognizing the connection as metered, suggesting that a more complex or vendor-specific approach may be required.

On January 2, 2024, the InControl system experienced an issue where many devices were falsely marked as offline due to a system component generating high CPU load on a memory database, which became overloaded. The issue was resolved by 07:12 UTC, with devices gradually appearing online again, and the system was fully recovered by 07:48 UTC.

Following the scheduled maintenance of the InControl 2 Mars system on September 27, 2021, users reported that Device Reports were missing most data on all units, and MediaFast Reports did not function with the SDX Pro.

To prevent future occurrences, fixes will be applied to only one planet at a time, additional resources have been added to the communications cluster, and the system will stop identifying devices as offline during high authentication volumes to avoid false alarms.

To delete an organization in InControl that was created with a personal email and is empty of devices, log in using that email, navigate to Organization Settings, and delete all devices on the device management page. The organization will be removed automatically after 28 days.

The InControl 2 Mars and Earth systems will undergo scheduled maintenance on November 14 and 28, 2022, at 00:30 GMT+0, lasting 60 minutes each, during which access to the system, Find My Peplink service, and captive portals may be less responsive or intermittently unavailable. The systems will be upgraded to version 2.12.0. The maintenance for the Earth system has been rescheduled to November 28 due to a potential performance issue identified in the release, and no maintenance was carried out on November 21.

The IC2 platform allows for tracking data usage by IMSI or ICCID per SIM card or across groups of SIMs when using Data pools from MVNOs. Partners have successfully built in-house systems utilizing the IC2 API to extract necessary data for monitoring and reporting purposes.

The InControl 2 Mars system will be upgraded to version 2.9.2 on September 27, 2021, at 00:30 GMT+0, with scheduled maintenance lasting 60 minutes. During this time, access to the system, Find My Peplink service, and captive portals may be less responsive or intermittently unavailable. The WAN quality reports in version 2.9.2 are noted to be easier to read, with improved chart intelligibility and hover functionality.

The InControl Mars and Mercury systems are undergoing scheduled maintenance on June 9, 2021, at 00:30 GMT+0, lasting 60 minutes. During this time, access to the systems and captive portals may be less responsive or intermittently unavailable. The upgrade will merge the Mercury system into Mars, with organizations on Mercury appearing on Mars after the upgrade.

InControl version 2.8.6 was deployed to the Mercury system, during which an issue with PepVPN configuration was identified. However, due to a configuration protection mechanism, no impact was made to any devices. The deployment to the Mars system has been postponed to September 8 at 00:30 GMT+0.

Currently, there is no report available that shows SIM ID, IMEI, and MDN together for data usage. However, there is a SIM data usage export tool under 'Sim Pool Reports' that is IMSI based. Additionally, SIM usage data can be accessed through Peplink's API services, which also operates on an IMSI basis, with endpoints available for hourly, daily, and monthly SIM usages.

Documentation and tutorials for InControl 2, including information on the Ads module and advertisement reports, can be found at the Ad Delivery Service Portal and the Ad Delivery Service Evaluation Guide. These resources provide insights into the capabilities of the Ads module and the types of reports available.

After scheduled maintenance on April 16 at 03:00 GMT+0, some Peplink and Pepwave client units were reported offline in IC2, affecting the Captive Portal functionality. Service was restored at 04:30 GMT+0.

To add users in InControl2, once a person is added, they will receive an email with a unique link. If the email is not received, the user can go to the InControl2 login page and select the 'Reset' option next to 'Forgot your password?' to receive a password reset email by entering their email address and clicking the Send button.

To set up email notifications for WAN connection status on a Peplink Balance, users can navigate to Group > Settings > Notifications to create multiple notification profiles for various purposes. This allows for more reliable notification management compared to using the CE device for sending alerts.

To move a device from one group to another within InControl, navigate to the Group Dashboard page, click on Manage, select the device by ticking the corresponding box, and then use the Actions pull-down menu to select Move.

Currently, InControl 2 (IC2) requires devices to be under warranty for management. If a device goes out of warranty, users must either renew the warranty or purchase an IC2 subscription to continue utilizing the management features. The subscription is considered affordable given the extensive capabilities that IC2 offers.

To query the status of a GPIO pin on Peplink routers, you can use the API endpoint 'https://192.168.50.1/api/status.gpio.input?list', which returns the status including voltage and type of the GPIO pin. For example, the response indicates the voltage level and whether the GPIO is enabled. This allows for monitoring the input voltage of the router.

To change the Master and Slave roles in a 1+1 Backup High Availability pair, the following steps should be followed: log into the Master device and uncheck 'Resume Master Role after Recovery' in the High Availability settings, then reboot the Master device. Next, log into the previously Slave device, disable configuration sync, set its preferred HA role to Master, and then log into the previously Master device to set its preferred HA role to Slave, entering the serial number of the new Master device. Finally, reboot the Slave device. This procedure allows for a successful role change without issues, provided both devices are connected to the same switch.

The Balance 710 HW1 experiences issues where it loses outbound WAN connection upon saving changes made to the unit. This problem occurs not only when changing outbound policies but also when modifications are made in the firewall section and inbound access services section. After applying changes, the unit may restart or fail to accept outbound/inbound WAN connections.

The Peplink BA310v2 experienced spontaneous restarts, which were suspected to be hardware related. After replacing the original power supply unit (PSU) with a different make and model, the reboot issues were resolved. When replacing a PSU, it is crucial to ensure that the voltage is identical, the polarity matches, and that the PSU can supply sufficient power to avoid damage or stability issues.

To inform DHCP clients that they are on a metered connection, one approach involves using DHCP option 43, which can be configured on Peplink routers. Additionally, Windows may utilize vendor extensions to convey network cost information through a specific packet format, where the cost level indicates the type of connection (e.g., unrestricted, fixed, variable) and cost flags provide details about usage conditions (e.g., over data limit, congested, roaming).

In Peplink routers, while it is possible to set various DHCP options, including option 43, there is no configuration option available to force the sending of option 43 in DHCP replies without it being specifically requested by the client. This behavior is noted as potentially necessary for clients to recognize a connection as metered, similar to how Android devices handle metered connections. However, testing indicates that simply setting option 43 does not achieve the desired outcome of clients automatically recognizing the connection as metered, suggesting that a more complex or vendor-specific approach may be required.

On January 2, 2024, the InControl system experienced an issue where many devices were falsely marked as offline due to a system component generating high CPU load on a memory database, which became overloaded. The issue was resolved by 07:12 UTC, with devices gradually appearing online again, and the system was fully recovered by 07:48 UTC.

query: How can a technician monitor and interpret the power supply input voltage and GPIO status on a Peplink router, and what steps should they take if voltage-related instability or restarts occur?
answer: A technician can monitor the power supply input voltage and GPIO status on a Peplink router by using the Router API. The API provides endpoints (such as '/api/status.gpio.input?list') that return the voltage and status (including type and enabled state) of GPIO pins, allowing the technician to check the input voltage remotely. If the router experiences instability or restarts that are suspected to be related to the power supply, the technician should ensure that any replacement power supply matches the required voltage and polarity, and that it can supply sufficient power. Using a power supply with incorrect voltage, polarity, or insufficient current capacity can cause reboot issues or damage the unit. Therefore, proper monitoring and correct PSU selection are both critical for stable operation.

citations.claim: The Peplink Router API can be used to query the status of GPIO pins and the power supply input voltage.
The API endpoint '/api/status.gpio.input?list' returns the status, including voltage, of GPIO pins on Peplink routers.
If a Peplink device experiences spontaneous restarts, it may be due to hardware issues with the power supply unit (PSU).
Replacing the PSU with one that matches the required voltage, polarity, and sufficient current capacity can resolve reboot issues.
Using an incorrect PSU (wrong voltage, polarity, or insufficient power) can cause damage or instability to the router.

The Peplink Pepwave Surf On-The-Go Wi-Fi Router (SUS-AGN1) can be used to provide internet access via public Wi-Fi or a mobile hotspot to a laptop through an Ethernet cable. It is capable of bridging the interface, allowing a virtual machine in VirtualBox to receive its own IP address on the Ethernet connection, as the router treats the virtual machine as a separate device.

## Document_2

The Pepwave Max On The Go (MOTG) is suitable for connecting multiple USB 4G/LTE modems to a laptop for video file transfer; however, it only supports load balancing and does not provide bonding capabilities. For bonding, a Peplink Balance 210 router is recommended, which would be necessary for combining multiple connections effectively in the transmission path.

## Document_3

For load balancing and failover of two 15Mb DSL connections with 15 users and 50 devices including VoIP and VPN support, the PepLink Balance 030 may not be adequate as it is recommended for up to 25 simultaneous users/devices. The Balance One is suggested as a more suitable option for this configuration.

## Document_4

For live video streaming using the Pepwave MAX On-The-Go with SpeedFusion, it is recommended to also have a compatible Peplink Balance device to utilize SpeedFusion bonding technology effectively. While the MAX On-The-Go can function as a load balancer, integrating it with a Peplink Balance on the streaming server side will enable the creation of a bonded connection that combines multiple WANs for improved bandwidth and reliability.

## Document_5

For live video streaming using the Pepwave MAX On-The-Go with SpeedFusion, it is important to prioritize RTP over IP using Quality of Service (QoS) settings. A QoS application rule should be added on both the streaming device and the server side, specifying 'Audio Video Streaming' and 'RTP' as the application to ensure optimal performance during streaming.

## Document_6

For live video streaming using the Pepwave MAX On-The-Go with SpeedFusion, it is important to configure Quality of Service (QoS) settings. This can be done in the Balance under Network > QoS > Application and on the MAX OTG under Advanced > QoS > Application. The supported application category for streaming is 'Audio Video Streaming' with the application set to 'RTP'. Additionally, custom applications can be added for prioritization using DSCP values.

## Document_7

When using the Pepwave MAX On-The-Go with SpeedFusion for live video streaming, it is important to consider the quality of the connections being bonded. It is recommended to use connections with similar latency and throughput for optimal performance. If bonding a high latency VSAT connection with a low latency fiber connection, it is advisable to set the fiber connection as priority 1 and the VSAT as priority 2 in the SpeedFusion profile to ensure traffic primarily routes through the fiber connection while allowing for real-time failover to the VSAT connection, creating an 'Unbreakable' connection.

## Document_8

On the Data Center side, a Peplink Balance router can be used to terminate the channel and provide a direct WAN connection to the internet for streaming to platforms like YouTube.

For live streaming with increased bandwidth, the Pepwave MAX On-The-Go or MAX 700 are suitable mobile routers that provide more bandwidth through multiple sessions or streams and offer instant fail-over between USB modems. To achieve better bandwidth for live streaming, using a Pepwave Max On-The-Go 3G/4G Router with Load Balancing and SpeedFusion is recommended. The traffic should be routed across the SpeedFusion VPN tunnel to a Peplink device located at a headquarters or datacenter, which will then connect to streaming services like Dacast or Livestream.

For live video streaming in a mobile camera crew environment, a recommended solution involves using a MAX On-The-Go equipped with multiple 3G/4G LTE USB keys for bandwidth bonding. The MAX On-The-Go sends the video stream to a Balance 380 via a SpeedFusion connection, which then connects to the broadcaster's media server through a landline. However, users have reported poor performance with multiple bonded LTE connections compared to using a single USB stick without SpeedFusion, indicating potential issues with the technology's optimization.

To establish SpeedFusion bonding for live video streaming using a Pepwave MAX On-The-Go, it is necessary to configure the MAX On-The-Go device to connect with the SpeedFusion Server Software installed on Amazon Cloud. This setup allows for bandwidth bonding between multiple cellular connections, enabling seamless live coverage for mobile camera crews.

For live video streaming using a MAX On-The-Go and Balance 380, the setup allows for bandwidth bonding between multiple 3G or 4G LTE connections. query: How do you achieve reliable, high-bandwidth live video streaming from a mobile camera crew using multiple 3G/4G LTE connections, and what are the critical configuration steps and considerations for SpeedFusion bonding with Pepwave MAX On-The-Go and Peplink Balance devices?
answer:
To achieve reliable, high-bandwidth live video streaming from a mobile camera crew using multiple 3G/4G LTE connections, deploy a Pepwave MAX On-The-Go router equipped with multiple USB 3G/4G LTE modems. Use SpeedFusion bonding technology to combine the bandwidth of these connections. The MAX On-The-Go sends the video stream via a SpeedFusion VPN tunnel to a Peplink Balance device (such as Balance 380) at the broadcaster’s media server location or data center, which then connects to the streaming platform via a landline.

Critical configuration steps include:
1. Configure SpeedFusion bonding between the MAX On-The-Go and the Balance device. On the MAX On-The-Go, define the remote IP, remote ID, and password for the SpeedFusion server (Balance or FusionHub); the remote server sets the password and local ID.
2. Prioritize audio and video traffic using QoS settings on both the MAX On-The-Go (Advanced > QoS > Application) and the Balance device (Network > QoS > Application), specifying ‘Audio Video Streaming’ and ‘RTP’ for optimal streaming performance.
3. Use WAN connections with similar latency and throughput for best bonding performance; if mixing high-latency (e.g., VSAT) and low-latency (e.g., fiber) connections, prioritize the lower-latency link in the SpeedFusion profile for primary routing, with the higher-latency link as failover.
4. Adjust MTU and UDP packet sizes as needed to avoid packet loss, e.g., set WAN1 MTU to 1300 and keep UDP packets at or below 1200 bytes.
5. Consider using MAX routers with built-in modems for reliability over long durations, as USB dongles may encounter issues in extended use.

Additionally, firmware enhancements (e.g., latency cut off and packet loss pull back) and features like WAN Smoothing are available to further improve reliability and performance over cellular links. For best results, consult the SpeedFusion best practice handbook.

BitTorrent traffic can be blocked using the Content Blocking feature or by following available guides for blocking such traffic. WAN smoothing reduces latency and packet loss by duplicating packets across both links, ensuring higher reliability for real-time voice and video. Outbound policies should prioritize traffic for these applications through the SpeedFusion tunnels, ensuring critical traffic uses the most reliable path. Technicians should be aware of Starlink's typical packet loss (around 1%) and higher latency compared to 5G; WAN smoothing and Forward Error Correction (FEC) help mitigate these issues. Session persistence is maintained during failover when using SpeedFusion, so calls and video streams remain active even if one connection drops. It is important to set the MTU to 1500 and use frequent health checks to stabilize Starlink links. Technicians should also be mindful that overall latency in a bonded connection is determined by the slowest link (often Starlink), so performance tuning may involve adjusting which applications use the bonded tunnel versus direct 5G. Lastly, proper naming of WAN connections and careful management of SpeedFusion overhead (about 18%) are important for optimal configuration and troubleshooting.

citations.claim: SpeedFusion bonds Starlink and 5G to improve reliability and performance for real-time apps like Zoom and Teams.
WAN smoothing reduces packet loss and jitter, critical for real-time applications, by sending duplicate packets across connections.
Outbound policies can prioritize Zoom and Teams to use SpeedFusion tunnels for best performance and failover.
Starlink typically has about 1% packet loss; WAN smoothing and FEC help mitigate this.
Session persistence is maintained with SpeedFusion hot failover, keeping calls active during outages.
MTU should be set to 1500 and health check intervals adjusted for Starlink to prevent false failover.
Bonded tunnel latency is determined by the slowest link; Starlink can raise overall latency when bonded with 5G.
SpeedFusion overhead is about 18%, and correct WAN naming is important for rule matching.

query: How should a technician troubleshoot persistent WiFi authentication failures on a Pepwave Surf Soho Mk3 network using WPA2-Personal, and what steps should be taken regarding firmware and client device settings?
answer: To troubleshoot persistent WiFi authentication failures on a Pepwave Surf Soho Mk3 network configured with WPA2-Personal, the technician should first ensure that the WiFi security setting is explicitly set to WPA/WPA2-Personal and that the correct pre-shared key is applied on both the router and client devices. If issues persist, reset the wireless SSID pre-shared key and delete any saved WiFi profiles on the affected client devices before reconnecting. The technician should also verify that the router is running the latest compatible firmware (at least version 6.2.0 or newer), as older firmware may have unresolved compatibility or stability issues. If authentication failures continue, check client device compatibility with WPA2 and consider disabling advanced features such as WPA3, PMF (802.11w), or 802.11k/r/v extensions on the AP, as these may cause connectivity problems. Testing with another access point configured identically can help isolate whether the issue is specific to the Soho Mk3 or the client devices.

query: A technician is troubleshooting a Pepwave MAX BR1 Mini that is stuck on 'Obtaining IP Address' with an AT&T SIM card, even though the SIM works in another device. What multi-step, evidence-based process should they follow to resolve the issue, considering APN settings, firmware, SIM compatibility, and device configuration?
answer:
To resolve a Pepwave MAX BR1 Mini stuck on 'Obtaining IP Address' with an AT&T SIM (which works in another device), the technician should:

1. Verify the SIM card and plan are active, appropriate, and permitted for use in routers, not just phones, as some phone SIMs or plans are incompatible with routers (Documents 20, 27, 28, 29, 30, 37).
2. Check and explicitly set the APN to the correct value for the AT&T plan (often 'broadband', 'phone', or 'nxtgenphone' depending on SIM type and plan), and avoid the 'auto' setting (Documents 1, 5, 14, 18, 19, 27, 39).
3. Ensure the device is running the latest firmware, as updates often resolve cellular connectivity issues (Documents 1, 4, 12, 15, 17, 24, 27, 38, 39).
4. Adjust device settings: Try changing Network Mode between 'Auto', 'Generic', and 'AT&T Only'; toggle between LTE/3G/Auto; and consider switching Operator settings between 'Auto' and 'Custom' (Documents 6, 12, 15, 16, 32).
5. If the issue persists, test the SIM in another device to confirm it is not defective, and test a known-good SIM in the BR1 Mini to check for device-specific issues (Documents 8, 9, 16, 22).
6. If all above steps fail, generate a diagnostic report and contact Peplink support, enabling Remote Assistance if possible (Documents 7, 17, 20).

Note: Signal strength alone does not guarantee connectivity; configuration must match carrier requirements (Document 39).

Set the APN explicitly to the correct value for the AT&T plan (commonly 'broadband', 'phone', or 'nxtgenphone'), and avoid 'auto' APN where possible.
Update the device to the latest firmware to resolve known connectivity issues.
Adjust device settings: Try different Network Modes, LTE/3G/Auto, and Operator settings ('Auto', 'Generic', or 'AT&T Only').
Test the SIM in another device and a known-good SIM in the BR1 Mini to isolate the issue to the SIM or device.
If the issue persists, collect diagnostic files and contact Peplink support, enabling Remote Assistance if possible.
Strong LTE signal does not guarantee connectivity if device settings are not aligned with carrier requirements.

query: What troubleshooting steps and configuration upgrades are recommended when a Pepwave Max BR1 Mini with a Verizon LTE SIM experiences significantly lower download speeds compared to upload speeds, including hardware, firmware, and network factors?
answer: When a Pepwave Max BR1 Mini with a Verizon LTE SIM is experiencing significantly lower download speeds than upload speeds, several troubleshooting and upgrade steps should be considered. First, update both the router and modem firmware to ensure optimal performance and compatibility with network changes. Next, examine the SINR value; a poor signal-to-noise ratio indicates that repositioning the antenna could help improve download speeds. Finally, utilizing the Max BR1 Mini Cat6 variant, which supports carrier aggregation and improved MIMO antenna technology, could significantly boost download speeds and overall performance.

query: When troubleshooting a Pepwave device that is stuck at 'Obtaining IP Address' with a cellular SIM, what multi-step process—covering SIM compatibility, carrier restrictions, and device settings—should a technician follow to isolate the issue?
answer: A technician should first confirm that the SIM card is the correct size and type for the device, as Pepwave models require specific SIM form factors and LTE/LTEA variants may require different SIM types. If the SIM card is recognized but still stuck at 'Obtaining IP Address,' the technician should check for carrier-specific restrictions, such as whether the SIM is locked to certain IMEI numbers or registered to the device (as is the case with some Sprint and T-Mobile SIMs). The APN settings should be verified for accuracy, as incorrect APNs can prevent IP assignment. The technician should also try the SIM in another device, if permitted, to rule out a SIM fault—but note that moving the SIM to a device with a different IMEI may cause the carrier to block it from the Pepwave in the future. If the SIM works elsewhere, the issue likely lies with the Pepwave device, requiring checks of cellular settings (carrier/generic mode), PRL updates, resets, and possibly a firmware update—although the latter requires an alternate internet connection. Throughout, the technician should be cautious about carrier practices that track SIM use by IMEI, as this can cause compatibility issues if the SIM is swapped between devices.

## Document_1

VPC (Virtual Port Channel) is a layer 2 technology that allows devices to connect to two Nexus switches simultaneously without creating loops, utilizing a PE link for traffic management. VXLAN (Virtual Extensible LAN) is an overlay technology that encapsulates layer 2 frames into IP packets for transport over a layer 3 underlay network, typically arranged in a spine-leaf topology for scalability. When integrating VPC with VXLAN, it is crucial to maintain a PE link between Nexus pairs and configure loopback interfaces correctly, including a secondary IP that must be identical on both switches. Best practices include using different loopback interfaces for BGP peering and NVE interfaces, implementing a delay restore command for VPC recovery, and ensuring spanning tree is enabled with a 4-second hello time. Additionally, a backup routing SVI can be created to maintain connectivity in case of uplink failures, and specific commands may be required for certain switch models to ensure proper VXLAN functionality.

## Document_2

The video discusses configuring VXLAN with EVPN in a network topology involving two switches and multiple tenants. It begins with setting up the underlay network, including configuring OSPF and MTU sizes, and then moves on to the overlay configuration, enabling BGP for peering and setting up an anycast gateway. The configuration includes creating Layer 3 VNIs, associating them with VLANs, and setting up route distinguishers and targets for BGP. The use of head-end replication for multicast traffic is highlighted, along with ARP suppression to improve efficiency. The process of adding tenants and verifying configurations through various commands is also covered, demonstrating the separation of tenant traffic and the functionality of the network setup.

## Document_3

The video discusses the configuration of EVPN (Ethernet Virtual Private Network) for multiple tenants using VNI (Virtual Network Identifier) in a network environment. It details the creation of a new tenant with specific configurations, including the use of VLANs and enabling IP forwarding. The anti-cast gateway is set as the default gateway for external networks, and the process of verifying the configuration is outlined using various commands such as 'show BGP l2vpn evpn summary' to check BGP neighbors and 'show NVE vni' to view VNIs associated with the VTEP (Virtual Tunnel Endpoint). The commands for troubleshooting and verifying connectivity, including ARP suppression and MAC address learning through BGP, are also highlighted. The separation of tenant traffic is confirmed through ping tests, demonstrating successful isolation of resources between tenants.

## Document_4

The video discusses the configuration of VxLAN using data plane learning on Nexus 9000 series switches. It begins with a basic topology involving two switches, each with a VTEP interface and a routed link simulating the underlay network. The configuration includes associating VLAN 1000 with VNI 5000, enabling OSPF for the underlay, and configuring multicast for BUM traffic. Key steps include setting the MTU to accommodate VxLAN headers, configuring access ports, and establishing loopback interfaces for the VTEP IP address and rendezvous point. The NVE interface is configured to encapsulate traffic, and verification commands are provided to check the status of the VTEP and VNI configurations. The video emphasizes the simplicity of data plane learning compared to control plane learning, which will be covered in a subsequent part.

## Document_5

VXLAN is an overlay technology that creates tunnels over an IP underlay network, utilizing ingress and egress VTEPs for traffic encapsulation and delivery. Address learning can be achieved through data plane learning, which is similar to traditional Ethernet, or control plane learning using BGP to share MAC address information. Unicast and BUM (Broadcast, Unknown Unicast, and Multicast) traffic types require different handling methods, with multicast being the preferred solution for scalability. Control plane learning allows switches to learn MAC addresses before they are needed, enhancing efficiency and providing VTEP authentication through BGP. Integrated routing and bridging are supported with BGP EVPN, allowing for both Layer 2 and Layer 3 VNIs, facilitating features like anycast gateway for virtual machine mobility. The configuration of these technologies will be explored in subsequent parts of the series.

## Document_6

The video discusses the spine-leaf topology, a network architecture often associated with VXLAN, which consists of two layers: the spine layer and the leaf layer. In this architecture, leaf switches connect to spine switches, with no direct connections between spine switches or leaf switches, ensuring a consistent topology and avoiding unnecessary paths. Each leaf switch has a link to every spine switch, and all links are routed, requiring IP addresses at each end. This design allows for equal path lengths and quick recovery from link or switch failures using Equal-Cost Multi-Path (ECMP) routing. The spine-leaf architecture is particularly suited for data centers, facilitating east-west traffic patterns and scalability by simply adding more leaf switches or links. VXLAN operates as an overlay on this architecture, enabling device mobility without IP address changes. Border leaf switches provide connectivity to external networks, integrating firewalls and routers, and managing route redistribution between the overlay and core routing protocols.

## Document_7

VXLAN (Virtual Extensible LAN) encapsulation is a technology that creates virtual Layer 2 segments called VNIs (VXLAN Network Identifiers) on top of a Layer 3 network. The process involves encapsulating an ordinary Ethernet frame, which may include a VLAN tag, into a VXLAN header that is added by a switch. The VXLAN header contains a 24-bit VNI, which allows for a large address space to support many VNIs. The encapsulated frame also includes UDP for transport, with a destination port of 4789 and a random source port for load balancing. An IP header and an Ethernet header are added for delivery, and upon reaching the destination, the headers are removed to deliver the original frame. The VXLAN header has reserved fields, with only one flag currently in use, and the additional headers can add around 50 bytes of overhead, necessitating the use of jumbo frames to avoid fragmentation and performance degradation.

## Document_8

VXLAN (Virtual Extensible LAN) is an overlay technology that simplifies network design by allowing virtual machines to communicate across different VLANs without changing IP addresses. It uses a 24-bit segment identifier called a VNI (Virtual Network Identifier), allowing for approximately 16 million unique segments, which is significantly more than the 4,000 VLANs supported by traditional VLAN IDs. VXLAN operates over an underlay network that is entirely Layer 3, eliminating the need for spanning tree protocols and trunking. Traffic is encapsulated in UDP and IP headers for transmission, and VXLAN can be implemented on both hardware and software, including hypervisors like ESX or Hyper-V. Each VXLAN-enabled switch or router has a special interface called a VTEP (VXLAN Tunnel Endpoint), which facilitates the connection between the overlay and underlay networks. This separation allows for changes in the underlay without redesigning the overlay, enhancing network flexibility and performance.

## Document_9

The video discusses the challenges and solutions related to configuring Virtual Port Channel (VPC) on Cisco Nexus switches, particularly in the context of routing protocols like OSPF. It highlights a scenario where routers and firewalls were not peering correctly with Nexus switches due to issues with TTL decrementing, which caused OSPF adjacencies to fail. The video explains that VPC is an enhanced link aggregation where traffic can be sent to either switch, but this can lead to packet drops if the TTL reaches zero. Solutions include ensuring routers are connected to switches with VPC, using orphan ports for peering, or changing links to routed ports. A key solution presented is the use of the 'layer three periodic' command in the VPC configuration, which stabilizes OSPF relationships, but requires the correct NX-OS version and hardware support.

## Document_10

The video outlines the configuration of a basic vPC (Virtual Port Channel) topology using two Nexus 9000 switches. The configuration process involves four main steps: enabling vPC and LACP features, configuring the keepalive link using management interfaces, setting up the vPC domain, and establishing the peer-link with two 40G ports in a port channel. The management ports are routed and can connect to a management network, while the keepalive link uses the management VRF. Switch 1 is designated as the primary switch with a priority of 10, and Switch 2 is set as the secondary with a higher priority. The peer-link configuration must be applied directly to the port channel, and member ports are associated with a vPC number. The video also explains orphan ports, which are normal ports without vPC configuration, and demonstrates how to identify them using the show vpc orphan ports command.

query: When integrating VPC and VXLAN technologies on Cisco Nexus switches in a spine-leaf topology, what are the key configuration and operational considerations to ensure proper functionality, scalability, and resiliency, especially regarding loopback interface usage, spanning tree, BGP/EVPN, and traffic encapsulation?
answer:
Successfully integrating VPC and VXLAN on Cisco Nexus switches in a spine-leaf topology requires careful attention to several configuration and operational details:

1. Maintain a PE (peer) link between Nexus VPC pairs to prevent loops and ensure proper traffic management. Configure the peer-link as a port channel and use the keepalive link for VPC health, as outlined in VPC best practices.
2. Use different loopback interfaces for BGP peering and NVE (Network Virtualization Edge) interfaces. The NVE loopback should have a secondary IP that is identical on both switches in the VPC pair for VXLAN overlay functionality.
3. Enable and properly configure spanning tree with a 4-second hello time to ensure loop avoidance and fast convergence in the VPC domain.
4. Implement BGP EVPN for control-plane MAC address learning and separation of tenant traffic. Configure Layer 3 VNIs for routing between segments, associate VLANs with VNIs, and set up route distinguishers and targets for BGP.
5. Ensure the MTU is increased (jumbo frames) to accommodate VXLAN encapsulation overhead (~50 bytes) and prevent fragmentation.
6. Deploy the spine-leaf topology, where each leaf connects to every spine, to achieve scalability and ECMP (Equal-Cost Multi-Path) resiliency. VXLAN overlays this underlay for device mobility and tenant isolation.
7. Optionally, configure a backup routing SVI to maintain connectivity during uplink failures.

By following these guidelines, the network will support scalable, resilient multi-tenant overlays with seamless integration between VPC and VXLAN technologies.

Enable and configure spanning tree with a 4-second hello time for loop avoidance and fast convergence.
