Captive portal management is centralized, supporting unified quota settings, various authentication methods (e.g., Instagram sign-in), and can be deployed globally to all devices or groups, reducing the need for local configuration.

Bulk configuration tools and zero-touch provisioning allow for efficient deployment and updating of Wi-Fi, SSID, and security settings across large numbers of devices, ensuring consistency and compliance.
InControl supports scheduling for SSID and AP availability, client access controls (e.g., max clients, minimum signal), and real-time reporting on Wi-Fi usage and client connections.
Organization-level access controls, two-factor authentication, and event logging ensure secure management and compliance across distributed networks.

## Document_1

The issue with the Pepwave Sure SOHO MK3's 2.4GHz SSID not allowing certain clients to connect after a period of time may be related to the WiFi connection between the affected clients and the router. While the 2.4GHz SSID is still visible, affected clients cannot connect to it after disconnection, although it reappears after some time. The problem does not affect all wireless clients simultaneously, suggesting it may not be a widespread issue with the MK3's WiFi functionality. Signal strength measurements of the affected clients may provide further insight into the problem.

## Document_2

The Max HotSpot supports Virtual WAN (VWAN) as it is compatible with firmware version 8.3, which includes this feature.

## Document_3

To resolve connection issues between a Peplink Balance One and a cable modem, it is recommended to change the Physical Interface Speed setting to 100M full duplex in the WAN configuration. Additionally, adjusting the 'advertise speed' option may also be necessary, either by checking or un-checking it, depending on the specific setup.

## Document_4

To configure a static route on a Peplink Balance 580 for reaching a remote subnet over a WAN link, one should use an outbound policy to direct traffic to the specific destination network via the desired WAN link, rather than attempting to configure static routes under LAN settings.

## Document_5

For a Peplink Balance 380 setup with IP forwarding, if the ISP's router does not support static forwarding, it is necessary to add a static route to the ISP router. This route should direct traffic intended for the 10.1.1.0/24 network to be forwarded via the Peplink router's IP address (192.168.1.254). Without this configuration, PCs on the 10.1.1.0/24 network will not receive responses for their internet requests. If static routes cannot be configured on the ISP router, the WAN on the Peplink B380 must operate in NAT mode to allow internet access.

## Document_6

To configure a static route on a Peplink Balance 380, navigate to the network settings, then LAN, and enter the destination network IP along with the appropriate subnet mask and gateway IP. For example, use a destination network IP like 10.181.34.0 with a subnet mask of 255.255.255.252 and a gateway of 10.181.32.1. Additionally, NAT mappings should be set up to map the local subnet IP to the WAN1 connection. It is also important to ensure that the point-to-point connection is properly connected and shows as active on the device.

## Document_7

To route traffic from a remote site directly to the internet using a Peplink Balance 380 appliance, a LAN static route can be configured to direct traffic from the remote site's subnet (192.168.2.0/24) through SpeedFusion to a specified gateway (192.168.1.252). It is also suggested to consider the use of a 0.0.0.0 netmask in future firmware updates for better routing capabilities. Additionally, it is important to confirm whether the HQ Peplink is functioning as the DHCP server for the local subnet (192.168.1.0/24).

## Document_8

To address WAN connection drops with a Peplink Balance One and a Motorola cable modem, changing the WAN speed setting from Auto to 100Mb and unchecking the 'advertise speed' option has proven effective in resolving communication issues. The user experienced several lost connections daily on Auto but has not encountered this problem since making the adjustment. It is noted that the internet service speed is lower than 100Mb, so this change does not impact the user's internet performance. The firmware version in use is 7.02.

## Document_9

The Peplink Balance 380 is experiencing intermittent time synchronization failures while running firmware version 6.3.2. Upgrading to firmware version 7.1 is a consideration, but there are concerns about potential VPN issues associated with that version. Users should be aware of these issues before proceeding with the upgrade.

## Document_10

There is a known issue with sorting the Download and Upload columns in the Client list of the Status section on the Balance One Core running firmware version 7.1. This sorting issue will be addressed in the upcoming firmware version 7.1.1, which is tentatively scheduled for release in late April.

## Document_11

To troubleshoot outbound PepVPN rules on a Peplink Balance running firmware version 6.2.0, it is recommended to use the ping command instead of trace routes, as trace routes do not function properly in an encrypted SpeedFusion tunnel. The PepVPN routes will not update on the Status > SpeedFusion page since they are learned routes. To verify the routing, initiate a constant ping from a local host to a remote host, then check the Status > Active Sessions on the Balance directing the traffic to the remote end. Filtering for ICMP packets will confirm if the traffic is using the intended tunnel, with packets appearing on the correct site and not on others.

## Document_12

To troubleshoot issues with page freezing while using a bonded ADSL setup on a Peplink Balance 20, it is suggested to connect one ADSL line directly to a PC to determine if the issue persists. If the freezing continues, it may indicate a problem with the ISP rather than the router or configuration. The firmware version in use is 5.4.6 build 1585.

## Document_13

The MAX BR1 Pro 5G is experiencing performance issues, with download speeds reported to be 100-200Mbps lower and upload speeds 10-20Mbps lower compared to other 5G products like the Netgear Nighthawk 5G, despite similar signal strengths and band usage. Users have noted that the device sometimes connects as 4G/LTE-A instead of 5G, with inconsistent connection type reporting on the dashboard. The firmware version 8.1.2 and subsequent updates have not resolved these performance issues, and users are questioning whether there are known bugs affecting the connection stability and speed optimization.

## Document_14

The most recent API documentation available for Peplink devices is for firmware version 8.3.0, and there is currently no documentation released for version 8.4.0.

## Document_15

The MAX Transit LTE-A device is running the latest 8.1.1 RC3 firmware. Users have experienced intermittent disconnections or failure to connect with M1 Macbooks, and disabling the 5GHz channel while using only the 2.4GHz channel has temporarily mitigated the issue, although this is not a long-term solution. One user reported no issues with their M1 Air on the same firmware version.

## Document_16

In Drop-in mode, support for VLAN clients to route traffic over the WAN was added in firmware version 8.1.0. This allows for the use of WAN1 from local networks even when in Drop-in mode, which may resolve issues related to VLANs not having internet access while the WAN is active. Configuration steps for Drop-in mode can be found in the user manual for firmware version 8.1.0.

## Document_17

To address missing NMEA information from a MAX TST modem, it is important to check the GPS antenna and its cable to ensure they are securely connected. Empty NMEA strings are often indicative of signal or reception issues, which could be affecting the modem's ability to provide complete data.

## Document_18

The Surf SOHO router has an option in the Web Admin interface that allows users to temporarily disable or block a specific device's WiFi connectivity. This feature is available in firmware version 8.1.3GA.

## Document_19

The Peplink Surf SOHO MK3 uses NAT to block unwanted inbound traffic, even though the default inbound firewall rule allows all traffic. The firewall rules are considered additional to the NAT function. By default, the firewall does not block any outbound ports unless specifically configured to do so.

## Document_20

The 's' in the firmware version indicates a special build firmware, which is often created by Peplink to include specific feature requests. For instance, firmware version 8.0.2s033 included features such as Firewall and Region/SaaS, which are later incorporated into the next general available firmware version.

## Document_21

In the context of Pepwave devices, VLANs do not have an on/off state; rather, it is the SSIDs that can be enabled or disabled. The schedule settings for SSIDs do not control the VLAN directly. Users should focus on the 'Enabled' checkbox for the SSID instead of relying on the schedule for VLAN management, as VLANs can be defined without being actively used.

## Document_22

Firmware version 6.3.1 is expected to contain a fix for connectivity issues experienced with certain devices on the LAN side of the Pepwave Surf SOHO router after upgrading to firmware 6.3.0, which caused two of the three devices to lose connectivity and not appear on the Status Client List.

## Document_23

The Surf Soho router running firmware version 6.1.2 has a bandwidth monitor that resets usage data based on the calendar month rather than the ISP billing cycle. Users have expressed a need for the ability to set the data monitor to align with their billing cycle for better tracking of data usage. Currently, the router does not support this feature, leading to confusion as users must manually calculate their data usage by combining the last days of the previous month with the current month's total.

## Document_24

To update the firmware on a Max BR1 Mini, access the web GUI by entering the device's IP address (192.168.50.1) and logging in with the default username and password (admin/admin). Check the current firmware version under the status tab; if it is 7.1.1, you must first upgrade to 7.1.2 before proceeding to 8.0. Download the necessary firmware files from the Peplink support site, ensuring to check the firmware archive for intermediate versions. Perform the upgrade by dragging the firmware file into the manual upgrade section of the web GUI. The upgrade process takes up to six minutes, indicated by the status light changing from red to green. After upgrading to 7.1.2, repeat the process to upgrade to 8.0, confirming the successful upgrade by checking the status page again. These steps apply to any Peplink or Pepwave device.

## Document_25

The Pepwave Sure SOHO MK3 is experiencing connectivity issues with its 2.4 GHz SSID, where devices can connect for a few hours before losing the ability to connect, although the SSID remains visible. The 5 GHz band continues to function without issues. The firmware version 7.1.0 operates correctly, while version 8.0.0 appears to cause connectivity problems after a period of time.

## Document_26

The Pepwave Sure SOHO MK3 is experiencing connectivity issues with the 2.4 GHz SSID, which connects for a few hours before stopping connections, while the 5 GHz SSID remains accessible. The issue appears to be related to firmware version 8.0.0, as the device operates normally on firmware version 7.1.0. For a requirement involving inbound and outbound ISP load balancing along with DNS server capabilities, a Peplink device can be configured to handle both functions. The device should be set up to manage DNS records, including A records, directly on the Peplink device instead of relying on a third-party DNS server. This setup will allow for the removal of existing DNS entries from the third-party vendor and ensure that the Peplink device handles all DNS configurations accordingly while balancing the ISP load.

An alternative solution is to use a FusionHub Solo in the cloud, allowing the Peplink 700 to make outbound connections to it, which can help manage inbound connections and maintain a consistent public IP address.

When creating outbound rules on a Peplink 310 to manage internet connections for uploads to a specific domain, it is important to understand that the server receiving requests cannot differentiate between upload and download paths based solely on the outbound rule. If an outbound rule is applied to a specific WAN IP for uploads, the corresponding download responses will also be routed through the same WAN IP, as the server does not have the capability to send responses to a different IP address than the one that initiated the request.

Both methods require the DNS service on the Peplink to be active to facilitate proper load balancing between the WAN connections.

The router acts as the authoritative DNS server for the domain, resolving the domain name to an active Public WAN IP. If a WAN link fails, the router will only respond to DNS requests with the Public IPs of WANs that are currently live, ensuring continuous connectivity without changing the public IP or causing disconnections.

## Document_1

Deep Packet Inspection (DPI) can be enabled on the SDX Pro through Incontrol2 by editing the device view. Once DPI is activated, users can access DPI reports under the reports menu in Incontrol2, which provides a breakdown of websites visited categorized by type.

## Document_2

To download event logs or reports of remote users connecting and disconnecting, one can utilize the InControl 2 API provided by Peplink, which allows for automation of this process.

## Document_3

When a captive portal is set up to collect user information such as email and other details, this information is stored and can be accessed easily by running a report in InControl2.

## Document_4

To ensure that HD2 and HD4 devices are receiving GPS signals, it is important to have a clear line of sight to the satellites. Simply placing the GPS antenna outside of a window may not be sufficient; it may be necessary to extend the antenna outside using a tripod or similar setup for optimal signal reception.

## Document_5

During the grace period for a Pepwave device, its features and access to InControl2 remain unaffected. Users can continue to utilize the device's capabilities without interruption during this time.

## Document_6

When attempting to import a firewall rule set from a configuration file on a PepWave MAX BR1 Mini, an error message indicating failure to extract firewall rules may occur. To manage firewall rules by group policy rather than by device, it is suggested to enable the 'Manage Firewall Rules on Balance and MAX devices' option at the group level in the InControl2 Web Portal before importing the configuration file. If issues persist, contacting the InControl2 team for support may be necessary.

## Document_7

The user is experiencing issues with a Peplink Balance 30 Pro router purchased from an Amazon seller, specifically regarding warranty registration and the activation of SpeedFusion. The warranty appears to be expired based on the serial number, indicating it may be old stock or previously registered. The user is unable to register the device in their Peplink account due to a discrepancy in the purchase date and warranty expiry date. Additionally, the management page shows a 'Speed connect' tab instead of 'SpeedFusion', and there are no eligible devices for activation.

## Document_8

To resolve issues with upgrading Peplink devices from firmware 8.0.0 to 8.0.2, it is advisable to check the InControl 2 (IC2) settings to ensure that it is not configured to push firmware 8.0.0 back to the devices, as this could cause the devices to revert to the older firmware after an attempted upgrade.

## Document_9

Devices need to be under warranty to be accessible through InControl 2. Some models may be eligible for a subscription-only model for continued access.

## Document_10

To remove a Peplink Balance One from the InControl panel, navigate to Organizational Settings, then Device Management. Select the device by clicking the checkmark next to it, and choose 'Remove' from the Actions menu.

## Document_11

For the Incontrol 2 API test page, the start field in the cellular signal GET request requires a date in the format YYYY-MM-DD.

## Document_12

For managing access points with a Pepwave MAX HD4, local AP management is a straightforward option, especially for users managing a limited number of devices. This approach allows for easier control without the need for utilizing the integrated AP controller of the router or the InControl2 setup.

## Document_13

Currently, there is no option to manually trigger the LED status light on AP One Enterprise devices to change or blink. However, this feature is planned for inclusion in a future firmware update, specifically targeted for version 3.6.1.

## Document_14

Although the AP One Flex is out of warranty, it is still possible to purchase an InControl 2 (IC2) subscription for the device. Users experiencing issues with warranty expiration should refer to the Peplink hardware warranty policy for further guidance.

## Document_15

All variants of the AP Pro operate in standalone mode. InControl 2 support for these devices is expected to be available in approximately 2-3 months, although no exact time-frame has been provided.

## Document_16

The AP One family of devices is expected to be supported by InControl 2 by the end of April. InControl 1 is reported to be functioning properly, but resources are currently being allocated to improve InControl 2.

## Document_17

The InControl 2 API does not support Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) and only supports requests made from server-side applications.

## Document_18

InControl2, the management platform for Peplink devices, is designed with security in mind, and two-factor authentication is mandatory for all managed customers to prevent unauthorized access. There have been no reported compromises among managed customers using InControl2, indicating a strong security posture.

## Document_19

The InControl subscription expiry date is displayed in the device details only if it differs from the warranty expiry date. If both dates are the same, as in the provided example, the expiry date will not be shown separately, indicating that the InControl subscription is valid until the warranty expiry date.

## Document_20

To use InControl2 for managing a Pepwave Surf Soho, one must first sign up at the InControl2 website, create an organization, and then a group to add the device by entering its serial number. This process allows for proper management of the Surf Soho device.

## Document_21

The false offline issue in InControl 2 (Earth) was resolved after approximately 8 hours, specifically at 10:00 GMT+0. However, currently about 40% of devices are unable to receive bulk configuration due to a known limitation, which is expected to be addressed in a future fix.

## Document_22

When the warranty for a Peplink device expires, the associated InControl 2 subscription also expires, causing the device to be deemed offline as it no longer reports to the InControl 2 cloud. To maintain access to InControl 2, a SmartCare license must be purchased to reactivate the warranty, which includes a new InControl 2 subscription. Alternatively, for some Peplink/Pepwave products, it is possible to purchase a standalone InControl 2 license at a lower cost than SmartCare.

## Document_23

The Warranty expiration date refers to the end of the hardware warranty and the InControl2 subscription. Users can opt for an extended warranty that includes the InControl2 subscription or a subscription-only option to continue using InControl2. If the subscription is not renewed, the devices will still function normally, but management through InControl2 will be lost.

## Document_24

To monitor websites visited by users on a home network using an SDX Pro, one can navigate to the Status -> Active Sessions page, which provides information on connected devices and allows for searching and sorting of active connections.

## Document_25

To resolve issues with upgrading Peplink routers (710, 580, and 380) from firmware version 8.0.0 to 8.0.2, it is important to check the firmware policy settings in IC2. If the policy is set to 8.0.2, disabling it and attempting a manual firmware installation may be necessary to successfully upgrade the firmware.

## Document_26

To resolve issues with updating Peplink devices from firmware version 8.0.0 to 8.0.2, it is recommended to manually download the desired firmware from the Peplink website and perform an offline update. After rebooting the devices, check the installed firmware versions and consult the Event Log for any relevant information regarding the update process.

## Document_27

For managing Pepwave access points, the choice between using the integrated AP controller of the MAX HD4 router or InControl2 depends on deployment requirements. For a small number of devices, local AP management may be sufficient. However, if remote access, device monitoring, and advanced features such as IC2 captive portal and reporting are needed, managing the access points through InControl2 is recommended.

## Document_28

If a Surf Soho device is out of warranty, it cannot be managed through InControl2. Users should contact their authorized Local Peplink Partner to explore options for returning the device to warranty or to inquire about the availability of an InControl2 only subscription, which may not be available for all models.

To continue using InControl 2 for monitoring WAN status without renewing subscriptions, it is necessary to have the appropriate license, such as ICS-012, purchased from the Peplink store. However, simply purchasing the license may not activate the service without entering the required data or configuration settings in the system.

query: How does the expiration of warranty and InControl2 subscriptions affect device management and what options are available for continued InControl2 access across different Peplink and Pepwave device models?

The InControl2 subscription expiry date is only displayed separately if it differs from the warranty date; otherwise, it is implied to match the warranty expiry. Users should check the Peplink hardware warranty policy and consult their Peplink Partner for device-specific options.

## Document_1

For high availability (HA) configurations with Peplink Balance 710 devices, using an active/active setup is recommended over an active/passive VRRP HA-pair due to the slow failover times associated with VRRP, which can exceed 30 seconds. In cases where compliance requires an active/passive configuration, VRRP may still be used, but it is considered cumbersome and outdated compared to active/active configurations that allow for faster failover and better resource utilization.

## Document_2

Peplink's high availability (HA) feature operates on a master/slave architecture, where one router is designated as the master and the other as a backup. The backup router remains inactive while the master is operational, only becoming active if the master fails. This implementation does not support a peer-to-peer relationship where both routers can independently manage their own WANs and VLANs while providing backup for each other. The HA configuration requires synchronization of settings between the master and slave, which is optional but necessary for the slave to be prepared for activation in case of a master failure. If synchronization is not enabled, the slave must be manually configured to match the master.

## Document_3

In a high availability (HA) setup using Peplink Balance routers in NAT mode, VRRP is utilized for WAN as well as LAN configurations. When properly configured, VRRP allows for the transfer of WAN addresses from the master router to the slave router in the event of a failure. This means that only one public IP address is needed for the HA setup, as the slave router will take over the master router's public IP address upon failure, rather than requiring multiple public IP addresses for each router.

## Document_4

In a high availability (HA) setup for Peplink Balance routers in NAT mode, the LAN configuration requires a Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol (VRRP) setup with a virtual IP (VIP) for the master and slave units. For the WAN configuration, two options are presented. Option 1 requires three VRRP groups: one for the LAN and one for each ISP, necessitating a total of six public IP addresses. Option 2 suggests a simpler configuration with only two public IP addresses, where the master unit handles both WAN connections and the slave unit takes over the WAN IP address upon failover. The WAN setup involves two ISPs, each with its own subnet and gateway.

## Document_5

In a High Availability (HA) setup using two Peplink Balance 380 routers configured with VRRP, issues may arise when both routers compete for the master role, particularly during internet connectivity loss. This can lead to network downtime as the routers transition between master and slave roles. The VRRP protocol relies on periodic advertisement packets sent from the master device to maintain the master-slave relationship. If both routers remain connected to the LAN and are aware of each other's WAN connectivity, conflicts over the master role can occur, especially if one router fails to recognize the recovery of the other after a power cycle. Proper diagnostics and physical connection details are crucial for troubleshooting these issues effectively.

## Document_6

query: How does Peplink's centralized management platform InControl enhance security, device configuration, and network performance across large deployments, and what specific features support these improvements?

## Document_1

For a work from home setup requiring reliable internet for VoIP and video calls, a Peplink Balance30LTE with SpeedFusion Cloud is recommended, as it provides stable connectivity even with multiple users streaming content. The user has successfully transitioned to using only Starlink and a local WISP, eliminating the need for LTE, and reports better stability compared to traditional ISPs. Future-proofing considerations include the potential for Starlink to achieve download speeds exceeding 200 Mbps, suggesting that specifications should be reviewed before purchasing a router.

## Document_2

For a stable internet connection in a rural setting with Starlink and Verizon cellular service, the Peplink Balance 20X is recommended, particularly for its SpeedFusion technology, which can manage interruptions from Starlink. This model can combine cellular and Starlink connectivity to enhance reliability. Additionally, older Verizon unlimited plans may allow for connected devices, providing an alternative cellular component for the router. Users can also consider setting up a new line on their family plan to use with the router's cellular WAN.

## Document_3

For a rural internet setup, the Peplink Balance 20 router is a suggested option, although it does not support WiFi-as-WAN, necessitating an additional device to connect a hotspot. The SpeedFusion VPN can be utilized to route critical traffic, allowing users to manage which applications go through the SpeedFusion tunnel and which do not, providing flexibility for different types of internet usage. Considerations for future needs include wiring for home security cameras and implementing parental controls for device access management.

## Document_4

In a setup using a Peplink Balance 210 with SpeedFusion bonding, WAN1 is a Verizon prepaid connection with variable speeds of 2 to 35 Mbps download and 6 to 10 Mbps upload, while WAN2 is a WISP connection with speeds ranging from 1 to 20 Mbps download and 1 to 10 Mbps upload. Preliminary tests showed that when using SpeedFusion bonding, the combined speeds were lower than expected, with download speeds dropping to 21.70 Mbps and upload speeds to 5.28 Mbps. Changing the SpeedFusion traffic distribution policy from Bonding to Lowest Latency improved performance, resulting in a download speed of 35 Mbps and an upload speed of 17 Mbps.

## Document_5

To bond two Starlink connections and provide failover to LTE using a Pepwave router, both Starlink connections can be plugged into the WAN ports of the Pepwave router. This setup allows for bonding of the Starlink connections while also enabling LTE failover. Additionally, a Peplink Balance 20 with a MAX adapter can be used to facilitate two wired WAN connections along with a USB cellular adapter for added redundancy.

## Document_6

In a setup using Pepwave HD4 with SpeedFusion, users have reported experiencing lower throughput when bonding multiple WAN connections. Specifically, with SpeedFusion enabled and the 'Send All Traffic to VPN' option selected, users observed a decrease in download and upload speeds compared to when SpeedFusion was disabled. The performance metrics indicated around 12 Mbit down and 6 Mbit up with SpeedFusion, despite having multiple SIMs from different carriers. Additionally, the 25 Mbit throughput license on FusionHub may impose limitations on overall performance. Best practices for SpeedFusion suggest that IMIX traffic flows can affect throughput, and users should expect some degradation in performance when bonding connections.

## Document_7

In testing bandwidth bonding with SpeedFusion on a Peplink HD4 MBX, users observed that while individual WAN connections provided good speeds (310Mbps and 230Mbps), the combined SpeedFusion performance was significantly lower than expected, averaging around 170-180Mbps with peaks of 190Mbps. The 200Mbps limitation of SpeedFusion Connect Protect servers and the inherent overheads of bonding, especially with fast WAN links, were noted as factors affecting performance. Enabling WAN smoothing resulted in even lower throughput, indicating that such features are designed for error correction rather than increasing capacity. The performance of Starlink terminals was also highlighted as variable, suggesting that combining different types of WANs may yield better results. Recommendations included considering the use of outbound policies for traffic management and potentially running a personal FusionHub for improved visibility and control over the SpeedFusion configuration.

## Document_8

Bandwidth bonding with SpeedFusion is a site-to-site VPN technology that is available on Peplink Balance 210 and higher routers. For users without a remote office, a virtual appliance called FusionHub can be deployed at a datacenter or on AWS cloud to facilitate bonding. Additionally, there is a service called Simply Bonding that manages the other side of the SpeedFusion tunnel using Peplink products.

## Document_9

To improve VPN and VOIP connection stability while using Starlink and a WISP connection with a Pepwave Surf SOHO, it is possible to configure SpeedFusion to bond the connections. However, it is important to note that WAN smoothing may need to be disabled if experiencing disconnections, as it can affect connection stability. The goal is to route traffic primarily through the Starlink connection and only utilize the WISP connection when Starlink is down, due to the bandwidth limitations of the WISP service.

## Document_10

To improve VPN and VOIP connections while using Starlink and a WISP connection, it is possible to configure SpeedFusion to bond the connections and route traffic to the WISP only when Starlink is down. For a setup that minimizes interruptions during video calls, a Peplink Balance 20 is suggested, which can facilitate seamless failover and connection bonding. Additionally, the use of SpeedFusion Cloud may be necessary for managing the connections effectively.

## Document_11

When bonding multiple internet connections, it is important to consider potential bottlenecks, such as limitations on the back-end of the Starlink service or the connection from the local antenna to the satellite. This can affect the overall throughput and effectiveness of bonding two connections, as they may compete for bandwidth if the backhaul is the limiting factor. The Peplink SpeedFusion 580 has a VPN throughput of 200 Mbps for FusionHub, which may be a concern for users needing higher bandwidth for applications like remote radiology exams that require significant data usage.

## Document_12

To achieve true bonding and increased download speeds by combining multiple connections on a Peplink device, SpeedFusion technology is required, which can be implemented through a FusionHub or another Peplink device. The SpeedFusion dynamic link bonding has an overhead of 18 to 30%, meaning that even with two 500 Mbps connections, the combined speed will not exceed 800 Mbps. Currently, the Peplink SDX can only perform load balancing without SpeedFusion, and users are advised to consult their Peplink partner or forums for optimization guidance.

## Document_13

To bond two Starlink connections and failover to LTE using a Pepwave router, SpeedFusion's WAN Smoothing can be utilized, which duplicates packets across both connections and selects the one with lower latency. However, this may lead to reduced bandwidth due to overhead. If both Starlink connections experience interruptions simultaneously, the setup may not be ideal as the benefits of bonding and smoothing cannot be achieved concurrently. Peplink's bonding technology has a maximum throughput of 200 Mbps, which may limit the benefits of using two Starlink connections. An alternative approach is to load balance the two Starlink connections for devices that do not require uninterrupted connectivity while creating a SpeedFusion VPN connection with WAN smoothing for devices that do, such as those used for video conferencing or gaming. Other bonding options include OpenMPTCP and Speedify, though they may have specific requirements or limitations.

## Document_14

Peplink's SpeedFusion technology allows for bandwidth bonding across various internet connections, including 4G, 5G, DSL, and satellite, without the need for specialized carrier connectivity. This dynamic bonding protocol enables the aggregation of multiple internet sources to enhance bandwidth and reliability, utilizing a packet-based approach rather than session-based methods. The technology has been successfully applied in various scenarios, such as bonding satellite connections for increased bandwidth and converting municipal networks to a bonded commodity internet solution, resulting in significant cost savings and improved performance. Peplink's engineers have continuously refined this technology over 18 years, allowing for flexible and scalable solutions that adapt to varying network conditions and requirements.

## Document_15

Peplink's SpeedFusion technology allows for efficient bandwidth management by creating sub-tunnels for different applications, enabling hot failover between various WAN connections such as fiber, broadband, and bonded 5G or Starlink. Each sub-tunnel can be configured with specific outbound policies tailored to the needs of applications like Microsoft Teams or Zoom, ensuring smooth performance even under varying network conditions. query: How can adding a slower or higher-latency WAN connection (such as a WISP) to a Peplink SpeedFusion-bonded setup with a faster connection (such as Verizon) negatively impact overall throughput, and what configuration adjustments can help mitigate this issue?
answer: When bonding a faster WAN connection (like Verizon cellular) with a slower or higher-latency WAN (like a WISP) using Peplink SpeedFusion, the overall throughput can decrease compared to using the faster connection alone. This is because SpeedFusion's bonding protocol distributes traffic across both links, and the slower or more jittery link can introduce delays or bottlenecks that reduce the effective combined speed. This effect is particularly evident if the WISP connection has higher latency or jitter, causing packets to arrive out of order or slower, which can throttle the performance of the entire bonded tunnel. Additionally, SpeedFusion bonding introduces overhead (typically around 18%), further reducing the maximum possible throughput. Configuration adjustments such as setting latency and packet loss cutoffs for the slower link can help by preventing it from being used when its performance degrades, thereby allowing the faster connection to carry more of the load. Properly tuning these parameters is crucial for optimal SpeedFusion performance, especially in areas with variable link quality.

Proper tuning of SpeedFusion parameters is necessary to optimize performance when bonding links with variable quality, especially in congested or rural areas.

In the context of a Pepwave Balance One, the first IPv6 address provided (fe70::256:caff:fe60:a391) is a link-local address, which is only accessible by devices directly connected to the Balance's LAN port. The second IPv6 address (2601:647:ce00:3cf9::bd06) is a global IPv6 address, which can be accessed by any device on the LAN or the internet.

## Document_4

Routing metrics are essential for determining the best route to remote networks, with common metrics including hop count, maximum transmission unit (MTU), bandwidth, latency, and administrative distance (AD). The hop count measures the number of routers between endpoints, while MTU defines the maximum packet size allowed. Bandwidth indicates connection speed, and latency measures the time taken for packets to traverse a network. Administrative distance ranks the trustworthiness of routing protocols, with lower values indicating higher trust. Route aggregation is a technique used to condense routing tables by summarizing contiguous routes, which requires careful planning to avoid noncontiguous networks. High availability techniques, such as Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP) and Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol (VRRP), are employed to eliminate single points of failure in networks by using redundant links and shared virtual IP addresses. Interior Gateway Protocols (IGPs) like OSPF and RIP are used within autonomous networks, while Exterior Gateway Protocols (EGPs) like BGP operate between different organizations. Routing protocols can be categorized into distance vector, link state, and hybrid protocols based on their routing determination methods.

## Document_5

IPv6 is routable and supports both static and dynamic routing protocols, including an upgraded OSPF version three that accommodates IPv6 alongside IPv4. To configure static routes in IPv6, the IPv6 route command is used, with a prefix length of 128 bits for host routes and ::/0 for default routes. IPv6 routing tables are independent of IPv4. OSPF version three can be configured using two methods: the traditional method similar to OSPF version two and a newer method utilizing address families to support both IPv4 and IPv6 simultaneously. Configuration steps include enabling IPv6 Unicast routing, starting the OSPF process, and assigning interfaces to OSPF processes without using the network command. The configuration also allows for the advertisement of default routes in the IPv6 address family, while maintaining separate routing tables for IPv4 and IPv6.

## Document_6

IPv6 introduces new methods for assigning addresses to devices, including EUI-64 and Stateless Address Auto Configuration (SLAAC), alongside traditional manual and DHCP methods. IPv6 supports dual stack configurations, allowing both IPv4 and IPv6 to operate simultaneously. Link local addresses are automatically generated when IPv6 is enabled, using the EUI-64 method which incorporates the MAC address of the network card. Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP) replaces ARP in IPv6, resolving IP addresses to MAC addresses and facilitating the discovery of routers and devices on the local network. NDP uses ICMPv6 messages for communication, including neighbor solicitation and advertisement messages. SLAAC allows devices to autonomously generate their own IP addresses based on router advertisements, making it stateless and eliminating the need for a centralized database of assigned IPs. The configuration of IPv6 addresses on routers involves using commands similar to those in IPv4, with the addition of CIDR notation for prefix lengths.

## Document_7

The video discusses the Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP) in IPv6, explaining how devices learn MAC addresses and detect IP conflicts through neighbor solicitation and advertisement messages. It introduces Stateless Address Auto Configuration (SLAAC), which allows devices to automatically configure their IP addresses without tracking assigned addresses, using router solicitation and advertisement messages to obtain prefixes. The client generates its own IP using the EUI-64 method. The video also covers the configuration of SLAAC on routers, including enabling IPv6 Unicast routing and suppressing router advertisement messages. Additionally, it explains the limitations of SLAAC regarding the lack of additional information like DNS servers, leading to the introduction of DHCPv6, which can be stateful or stateless. Stateful DHCP tracks leases and assigns IPs, while stateless DHCP works alongside SLAAC to provide additional configuration options. The video concludes with a lab exercise involving multiple routers to configure and troubleshoot IPv6 addressing.

## Document_8

IPv6 introduces several new address types including global unicast, local, and anycast addresses, aiming to eliminate the need for NAT and private IPs. Unlike IPv4, where NAT was essential due to limited public IPs, IPv6 allows all devices to have publicly routable addresses, although NAT technologies like NAT46 and NAT64 still exist for IPv4 to IPv6 translation. Link-local addresses, starting with 'fe80', are automatically assigned to interfaces for local communication and are not routable beyond the local network. Unique local addresses can be used within private networks but are not routable on the internet. IPv6 eliminates broadcast traffic, relying instead on multicast for similar functionality, and introduces anycast for load balancing across multiple devices. Subnetting in IPv6 is similar to IPv4, with common subnet sizes being /64, /56, or /48, allowing for efficient network design and allocation.

## Document_9

IPv6 addresses consist of eight groups of hexadecimal numbers separated by colons, contrasting with IPv4's four groups of decimal numbers separated by dots. Each hexadecimal group represents 16 bits, and leading zeros can be omitted for simplification. Consecutive groups of zeros can be compressed using a double colon, but only one such compression is allowed in an address. The standard prefix length for most subnets is /64, allowing approximately 18 quintillion addresses per subnet. IPv6 addresses are 128 bits long, and a /128 prefix indicates a host address, while /127 is used for point-to-point WAN links, allowing only two host addresses. The IPv6 header is larger than the IPv4 header but simpler, with fewer mandatory fields. The video also mentions various types of IPv6 addresses, including global unicast and local addresses.

## Document_10

The video discusses the evolution of Internet Protocol (IP), highlighting the separation of TCP and IP in 1977 and the subsequent adoption of TCP/IP as the standard for military networking in 1982. IPv4, which uses 32-bit addresses, supports approximately 4.2 billion unique addresses but is facing exhaustion due to the rapid growth of the internet and the increasing number of connected devices, including IoT devices. The introduction of NAT and CIDR helped extend the life of IPv4, but the long-term solution is IPv6, which utilizes 128-bit addresses, providing a vastly larger address space of 340 undecillion addresses. The video outlines the challenges of transitioning from IPv4 to IPv6, including the need for dual-stack configurations and the slow pace of adoption due to legacy applications and infrastructure. It also mentions enhancements in IPv6, such as the replacement of ARP with NDP, the introduction of DHCPv6 and DNSv6, and the elimination of broadcasts in favor of multicast messaging.

## Document_11

The video discusses the exhaustion of IPv4 addresses, noting that IANA allocated its last /8 block in January 2011, with various regional Internet registries (RIRs) exhausting their allocations in subsequent years. While IPv4 is not completely obsolete, its availability is severely limited, prompting a marketplace for buying and selling IP blocks. The long-term solution is IPv6, which offers a vastly larger address space and a different hexadecimal address format. IPv4 and IPv6 can coexist through dual stack configurations, facilitating migration. Key changes in IPv6 include the absence of traditional NAT, replaced by NAT64 and NAT46 for IPv4 to IPv6 translation, and the introduction of ICMPv6, DHCPv6, and DNSv6 with new record types. The Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) has been replaced by the Neighbour Discovery Protocol (NDP), and broadcasts have been eliminated in favor of multicast messaging, enhancing efficiency.

## Document_12

The transcript discusses the concept of Equal Cost Multi-Path (ECMP) routing, where Cisco routers can have up to four equal cost next hops per path in the routing table. It explains how OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) operates, including the use of the network command to enable OSPF on an interface and advertise networks. The concept of passive interfaces is introduced, which allows advertising a network without forming an adjacency with another router. The importance of having a network in the routing table before it can be advertised is emphasized, along with the process of redistributing a default route into OSPF using the 'default-information originate' command. The transcript also touches on the significance of route types in the routing table, specifically mentioning OSPF learned routes and their external source designation (E1 or E2).

## Document_13

Dynamic routing protocols, such as OSPF, facilitate the automatic learning and sharing of routes among routers, allowing for efficient network management as it grows. Unlike static routing, which requires manual configuration, dynamic protocols establish neighbor relationships through hello messages and share subnet information to build routing tables. These protocols automatically select the best path based on metrics, which measure the quality of paths, and can adapt to network changes, such as link failures, by updating routing tables accordingly. OSPF, a widely used Interior Gateway Protocol (IGP), assigns costs to links based on bandwidth, while EIGRP offers a more complex metric that considers multiple factors. BGP serves as an Exterior Gateway Protocol (EGP) for routing between different organizations. Routers can run multiple protocols simultaneously, and the routing table reflects the source of learned routes, indicated by specific codes for each protocol.

## Document_14

The video discusses various routing protocols, focusing on OSPF, BGP, EIGRP, and ISIS. OSPF organizes networks into areas for easier topology planning, while BGP can be used internally (iBGP) and externally (eBGP) and is highly tunable but complex. ISIS is robust but mainly used in large networks. Routers can run multiple protocols simultaneously, and the command 'show IP protocols' reveals all active protocols. The routing table indicates which protocol learned each route, with specific codes for static routes, OSPF, EIGRP, and BGP. The router selects the best path based on administrative distance (AD) when routes from different protocols are available, with EIGRP having a default AD of 90 and OSPF 110. Equal Cost Multi-Path (ECMP) allows the use of multiple routes with the same AD and metric, enhancing load sharing. The video emphasizes the importance of understanding these concepts for further learning, particularly regarding OSPF configuration.

## Document_15

Dynamic routing protocols allow routers to automatically learn and share route information, enabling them to adapt to changes in the network without the need for extensive manual configuration of static routes. This adaptability is crucial for maintaining network reliability, especially in environments with many routers. The longest prefix match (LPM) rule is essential for determining which route to use when multiple valid routes exist; the router will select the route with the most specific subnet mask. Additionally, routers use administrative distance values to prioritize routes learned from different sources, with lower values indicating more trusted sources. Floating static routes can be configured as backups with higher administrative distances to ensure redundancy in case primary routes fail, allowing for seamless failover between high-speed and low-speed links.

## Document_16

The video discusses the behavior of static routes in a network, highlighting that shutting down an interface on a router will remove its static route from the routing table, leading to potential traffic loss if the route is still present on other routers. It explains that static routes can be configured with an outgoing interface instead of a next hop IP, which may be useful in small networks. The process of packet forwarding is described, detailing how routers check frame validity, decapsulate frames, and use routing tables to forward packets. The concept of a default route is introduced, which serves as a catch-all for destinations not explicitly listed in the routing table, with a destination network of 0.0.0.0. The video emphasizes the importance of practice in configuring static routing and understanding network topologies, suggesting challenges for viewers to reinforce their learning.

## Document_17

The video discusses the OSI model and various network devices categorized by their operational layers. Layer one devices include modems and hubs, which operate at the physical layer, with modems converting digital signals to analog and vice versa, while hubs replicate electrical signals across multiple ports. Layer two devices include switches and wireless access points (WAPs), with switches using ASIC chips to learn device MAC addresses and communicate within local networks, while WAPs bridge wireless and wired segments. Layer three devices include multi-layer switches and routers, with multi-layer switches providing both switching and routing capabilities, and routers connecting different networks using logical network information. The video also covers security devices such as firewalls, intrusion detection systems (IDS), and intrusion prevention systems (IPS), explaining their functions and operational layers. Firewalls can operate at multiple layers and protect networks by blocking packets, while IDS passively monitors for breaches, and IPS actively prevents attacks. Additionally, VPN concentrators facilitate secure connections and can operate at various OSI layers, and load balancers distribute workloads among multiple hosts for efficiency.

## Document_18

Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) monitor network traffic for potential breaches using signature-based, anomaly-based, or policy-based standards, but cannot prevent attacks on their own. In contrast, Intrusion Prevention Systems (IPS) actively block malicious activity and require all traffic to flow through them for effective operation. VPN concentrators facilitate secure connections for remote hosts through encrypted tunnels, functioning at various OSI model layers, primarily layer 3 for IPsec encryption. Load balancers distribute workloads among servers to enhance efficiency, while proxy servers act on behalf of clients to retrieve resources, filter content, and improve performance through caching. Various VPN types include site-to-site, remote access, and host-to-host, utilizing protocols like IPsec, GRE, PPTP, and TLS for secure connections, with TLS being the most common for modern applications.

## Document_19

The video discusses various networking protocols and services, focusing on VPN technologies such as IPSec, GRE, PPTP, and TLS. IPSec operates in tunnel mode for secure site-to-site VPN connections and uses IKE for key management. GRE allows encapsulation of multiple protocols and supports multicast and broadcast transmissions. PPTP, while older and less secure, can be enhanced with GRE. TLS is highlighted as a modern cryptographic protocol for secure connections, replacing SSL, which is now considered outdated. The video also covers network access services, specifically the Network Interface Controller (NIC), which connects devices to networks and operates at OSI layers 1 and 2, and RADIUS, a protocol for remote user authentication and authorization. Additionally, it explains the DHCP process for dynamic IP addressing, detailing how a DHCP server assigns IP configurations to devices, including the use of discovery, offer, request, and acknowledgment packets, as well as address scopes and reservations.

## Document_20

The DHCP process begins when a PC sends a DHCP Discovery packet to the broadcast address 255.255.255.0 on UDP Port 67. The DHCP server, listening on this port, responds with an offer packet sent to the PC's MAC address on UDP Port 68. The PC then sends a request packet to the DHCP server to accept the offer, and the server replies with an acknowledgement packet containing the IP configuration information. The DHCP server manages an address scope, which is the range of IP addresses it can assign, and can also reserve specific IP addresses for certain devices. Leases are assigned to IP configurations, with a time limit set by the administrator. The DHCP server can be configured to relay requests across network segments. In addition, the video discusses DNS, explaining that it maps human-friendly domain names to IP addresses. DNS servers include local servers, top-level domain servers, and root servers, with authoritative servers providing original records and non-authoritative servers relaying information. Various DNS record types are introduced, including A records for IPv4 addresses, AAAA records for IPv6 addresses, CNAME records for aliases, and MX records for email servers. Dynamic DNS allows for automatic updates to DNS records when IP addresses change, facilitating access to services with dynamic IPs.

## Document_21

An authoritative DNS server is configured to contain original records and responds directly to requests, while a non-authoritative DNS server provides information received from other servers. Key DNS record types include A records, which map hostnames to IPv4 addresses; AAAA records for IPv6 addresses; CNAME records for aliasing; and MX records for email server mapping. Dynamic DNS (DDNS) allows for automatic updates of DNS records when IP addresses change, facilitating access to services with dynamic IPs. Network Address Translation (NAT) enables routing of non-routable private IP addresses to public IP addresses, with static NAT assigning fixed public IPs and dynamic NAT using a pool of public IPs. Port Address Translation (PAT) enhances scalability by allowing multiple devices to share a single public IP address through unique port numbers. NAT terminology includes inside local addresses (private IPs), inside global addresses (public IPs for local devices), outside global addresses (public IPs for external devices), and outside local addresses (private IPs for external devices).

## Document_22

The video discusses various aspects of Wide Area Network (WAN) technologies, including Network Address Translation (NAT), the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN), and broadband technologies. NAT allows inside devices to communicate with outside devices by translating private and public IP addresses. The PSTN is a foundational WAN technology that supports dial-up and ISDN connections, with ISDN offering digital services through terminal adapters. DSL technologies, including SDSL, ADSL, and VDSL, utilize the PSTN for data transmission, with varying speeds and capabilities. Broadband cable networking delivers voice, data, and television through coaxial cables, requiring compliance with DOCSIS specifications. Fiber optic networking uses light for data transmission, providing higher bandwidth over longer distances and employing standards like SONET and SDH. The video also touches on GSM and CDMA cellular technologies, highlighting their incompatibility and the evolution of cellular networking from 1G to 4G, including HSPA+ as a transitional technology.

## Document_23

The video discusses various wide area network (WAN) technologies, including fiber optic networking, GSM and CDMA cellular connections, YMAX, and satellite WAN connections. Dense Wavelength Division Multiplexing (DWDM) allows for multiplexing up to 32 optical carrier levels into a single fiber optic cable, while Coarse Wavelength Division Multiplexing (CWDM) supports up to 8 channels. Passive Optical Networks (PON) utilize unpowered optical splitters for connecting multiple locations. GSM and CDMA are two incompatible cellular standards used in the U.S., with GSM being more widely adopted globally. The evolution of cellular networking is outlined from 1G to 4G, with LTE offering download speeds of up to 300 Mbps. YMAX provides an alternative broadband connection using microwave transmissions, requiring line of sight, and satellite WAN connections extend networks to hard-to-reach areas but may introduce latency due to the distances involved. Additionally, Metro Ethernet and leased line WAN connections are explained, with leased lines providing dedicated circuits that can utilize protocols like Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) for multiple data transmissions.

## Document_24

Leased lines can utilize either plain old telephone service (POTS) or fiber optic circuits, with costs borne solely by the customer due to exclusive use. The speed of leased lines is determined by the customer's budget, and technologies like Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) allow for multiple layer 3 protocols to be transmitted simultaneously. Multiplexing technologies can increase channel capacity, with T-carrier lines in the US and E-carrier lines in Europe providing various digital signal channels (DS0, DS1, DS3) with specific bandwidths. Fiber optic connections are categorized by Optical Carrier (OC) lines, with OC rates established by SONET and SDH standards, allowing for high-speed data transmission. Circuit-switched networks maintain a dedicated path for communication, while packet-switched networks break data into packets for more efficient routing. Frame Relay and Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM) are WAN technologies that differ in packet size and efficiency, with Multi-Protocol Label Switching (MPLS) offering a scalable solution for managing network traffic across different protocols.

IPv6 addresses are 128 bits long, and a /128 prefix indicates a host address, while /127 is used for point-to-point WAN links, allowing only two host addresses. The IPv6 header is larger than the IPv4 header but simpler, with fewer mandatory fields. The video also mentions various types of IPv6 addresses, including global unicast and local addresses.

The video discusses the evolution of Internet Protocol (IP), highlighting the separation of TCP and IP in 1977 and the subsequent adoption of TCP/IP as the standard for military networking in 1982. IPv4, which uses 32-bit addresses, supports approximately 4.2 billion unique addresses but is facing exhaustion due to the rapid growth of the internet and the increasing number of connected devices, including IoT devices. The introduction of NAT and CIDR helped extend the life of IPv4, but the long-term solution is IPv6, which utilizes 128-bit addresses, providing a vastly larger address space of 340 undecillion addresses. The video outlines the challenges of transitioning from IPv4 to IPv6, including the need for dual-stack configurations and the slow pace of adoption due to legacy applications and infrastructure. It also mentions enhancements in IPv6, such as the replacement of ARP with NDP, the introduction of DHCPv6 and DNSv6, and the elimination of broadcasts in favor of multicast messaging.

The video discusses the exhaustion of IPv4 addresses, noting that IANA allocated its last /8 block in January 2011, with various regional Internet registries (RIRs) exhausting their allocations in subsequent years. While IPv4 is not completely obsolete, its availability is severely limited, prompting a marketplace for buying and selling IP blocks. The long-term solution is IPv6, which offers a vastly larger address space and a different hexadecimal address format. IPv4 and IPv6 can coexist through dual stack configurations, facilitating migration. Key changes in IPv6 include the absence of traditional NAT, replaced by NAT64 and NAT46 for IPv4 to IPv6 translation, and the introduction of ICMPv6, DHCPv6, and DNSv6 with new record types. The Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) has been replaced by the Neighbour Discovery Protocol (NDP), and broadcasts have been eliminated in favor of multicast messaging, enhancing efficiency.

The transcript discusses the concept of Equal Cost Multi-Path (ECMP) routing, where Cisco routers can have up to four equal cost next hops per path in the routing table. It explains how OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) operates, including the use of the network command to enable OSPF on an interface and advertise networks. The concept of passive interfaces is introduced, which allows advertising a network without forming an adjacency with another router. The importance of having a network in the routing table before it can be advertised is emphasized, along with the process of redistributing a default route into OSPF using the 'default-information originate' command. The transcript also touches on the significance of route types in the routing table, specifically mentioning OSPF learned routes and their external source designation (E1 or E2).

Dynamic routing protocols, such as OSPF, facilitate the automatic learning and sharing of routes among routers, allowing for efficient network management as it grows. Unlike static routing, which requires manual configuration, dynamic protocols establish neighbor relationships through hello messages and share subnet information to build routing tables. These protocols automatically select the best path based on metrics, which measure the quality of paths, and can adapt to network changes, such as link failures, by updating routing tables accordingly. OSPF, a widely used Interior Gateway Protocol (IGP), assigns costs to links based on bandwidth, while EIGRP offers a more complex metric that considers multiple factors. BGP serves as an Exterior Gateway Protocol (EGP) for routing between different organizations. Routers can run multiple protocols simultaneously, and the routing table reflects the source of learned routes, indicated by specific codes for each protocol.

The video discusses various routing protocols, focusing on OSPF, BGP, EIGRP, and ISIS. OSPF organizes networks into areas for easier topology planning, while BGP can be used internally (iBGP) and externally (eBGP) and is highly tunable but complex. ISIS is robust but mainly used in large networks. Routers can run multiple protocols simultaneously, and the command 'show IP protocols' reveals all active protocols. The routing table indicates which protocol learned each route, with specific codes for static routes, OSPF, EIGRP, and BGP. The router selects the best path based on administrative distance (AD) when routes from different protocols are available, with EIGRP having a default AD of 90 and OSPF 110. Equal Cost Multi-Path (ECMP) allows the use of multiple routes with the same AD and metric, enhancing load sharing. The video emphasizes the importance of understanding these concepts for further learning, particularly regarding OSPF configuration.

Dynamic routing protocols allow routers to automatically learn and share route information, enabling them to adapt to changes in the network without the need for extensive manual configuration of static routes. This adaptability is crucial for maintaining network reliability, especially in environments with many routers. The longest prefix match (LPM) rule is essential for determining which route to use when multiple valid routes exist; the router will select the route with the most specific subnet mask. Additionally, routers use administrative distance values to prioritize routes learned from different sources, with lower values indicating more trusted sources. Floating static routes can be configured as backups with higher administrative distances to ensure redundancy in case primary routes fail, allowing for seamless failover between high-speed and low-speed links.

The video discusses the behavior of static routes in a network, highlighting that shutting down an interface on a router will remove its static route from the routing table, leading to potential traffic loss if the route is still present on other routers. It explains that static routes can be configured with an outgoing interface instead of a next hop IP, which may be useful in small networks. The process of packet forwarding is described, detailing how routers check frame validity, decapsulate frames, and use routing tables to forward packets. The concept of a default route is introduced, which serves as a catch-all for destinations not explicitly listed in the routing table, with a destination network of 0.0.0.0. The video emphasizes the importance of practice in configuring static routing and understanding network topologies, suggesting challenges for viewers to reinforce their learning.

The video discusses the OSI model and various network devices categorized by their operational layers. Layer one devices include modems and hubs, which operate at the physical layer, with modems converting digital signals to analog and vice versa, while hubs replicate electrical signals across multiple ports. Layer two devices include switches and wireless access points (WAPs), with switches using ASIC chips to learn device MAC addresses and communicate within local networks, while WAPs bridge wireless and wired segments. Layer three devices include multi-layer switches and routers, with multi-layer switches providing both switching and routing capabilities, and routers connecting different networks using logical network information. The video also covers security devices such as firewalls, intrusion detection systems (IDS), and intrusion prevention systems (IPS), explaining their functions and operational layers. Firewalls can operate at multiple layers and protect networks by blocking packets, while IDS passively monitors for breaches, and IPS actively prevents attacks. Additionally, VPN concentrators facilitate secure connections and can operate at various OSI layers, and load balancers distribute workloads among multiple hosts for efficiency.

Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) monitor network traffic for potential breaches using signature-based, anomaly-based, or policy-based standards, but cannot prevent attacks on their own. In contrast, Intrusion Prevention Systems (IPS) actively block malicious activity and require all traffic to flow through them for effective operation. VPN concentrators facilitate secure connections for remote hosts through encrypted tunnels, functioning at various OSI model layers, primarily layer 3 for IPsec encryption. Load balancers distribute workloads among servers to enhance efficiency, while proxy servers act on behalf of clients to retrieve resources, filter content, and improve performance through caching. Various VPN types include site-to-site, remote access, and host-to-host, utilizing protocols like IPsec, GRE, PPTP, and TLS for secure connections, with TLS being the most common for modern applications.

The video discusses various networking protocols and services, focusing on VPN technologies such as IPSec, GRE, PPTP, and TLS. IPSec operates in tunnel mode for secure site-to-site VPN connections and uses IKE for key management. GRE allows encapsulation of multiple protocols and supports multicast and broadcast transmissions. PPTP, while older and less secure, can be enhanced with GRE. TLS is highlighted as a modern cryptographic protocol for secure connections, replacing SSL, which is now considered outdated. The video also covers network access services, specifically the Network Interface Controller (NIC), which connects devices to networks and operates at OSI layers 1 and 2, and RADIUS, a protocol for remote user authentication and authorization. Additionally, it explains the DHCP process for dynamic IP addressing, detailing how a DHCP server assigns IP configurations to devices, including the use of discovery, offer, request, and acknowledgment packets, as well as address scopes and reservations.

The DHCP process begins when a PC sends a DHCP Discovery packet to the broadcast address 255.255.255.0 on UDP Port 67. The DHCP server, listening on this port, responds with an offer packet sent to the PC's MAC address on UDP Port 68. The PC then sends a request packet to the DHCP server to accept the offer, and the server replies with an acknowledgement packet containing the IP configuration information. The DHCP server manages an address scope, which is the range of IP addresses it can assign, and can also reserve specific IP addresses for certain devices. Leases are assigned to IP configurations, with a time limit set by the administrator. The DHCP server can be configured to relay requests across network segments. In addition, the video discusses DNS, explaining that it maps human-friendly domain names to IP addresses. DNS servers include local servers, top-level domain servers, and root servers, with authoritative servers providing original records and non-authoritative servers relaying information. Various DNS record types are introduced, including A records for IPv4 addresses, AAAA records for IPv6 addresses, CNAME records for aliases, and MX records for email servers. Dynamic DNS allows for automatic updates to DNS records when IP addresses change, facilitating access to services with dynamic IPs.

An authoritative DNS server is configured to contain original records and responds directly to requests, while a non-authoritative DNS server provides information received from other servers. Key DNS record types include A records, which map hostnames to IPv4 addresses; AAAA records for IPv6 addresses; CNAME records for aliasing; and MX records for email server mapping. Dynamic DNS (DDNS) allows for automatic updates of DNS records when IP addresses change, facilitating access to services with dynamic IPs. Network Address Translation (NAT) enables routing of non-routable private IP addresses to public IP addresses, with static NAT assigning fixed public IPs and dynamic NAT using a pool of public IPs. Port Address Translation (PAT) enhances scalability by allowing multiple devices to share a single public IP address through unique port numbers. NAT terminology includes inside local addresses (private IPs), inside global addresses (public IPs for local devices), outside global addresses (public IPs for external devices), and outside local addresses (private IPs for external devices).

The video discusses various aspects of Wide Area Network (WAN) technologies, including Network Address Translation (NAT), the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN), and broadband technologies. NAT allows inside devices to communicate with outside devices by translating private and public IP addresses. The PSTN is a foundational WAN technology that supports dial-up and ISDN connections, with ISDN offering digital services through terminal adapters. DSL technologies, including SDSL, ADSL, and VDSL, utilize the PSTN for data transmission, with varying speeds and capabilities. Broadband cable networking delivers voice, data, and television through coaxial cables, requiring compliance with DOCSIS specifications. Fiber optic networking uses light for data transmission, providing higher bandwidth over longer distances and employing standards like SONET and SDH. The video also touches on GSM and CDMA cellular technologies, highlighting their incompatibility and the evolution of cellular networking from 1G to 4G, including HSPA+ as a transitional technology.

The video discusses various wide area network (WAN) technologies, including fiber optic networking, GSM and CDMA cellular connections, YMAX, and satellite WAN connections. Dense Wavelength Division Multiplexing (DWDM) allows for multiplexing up to 32 optical carrier levels into a single fiber optic cable, while Coarse Wavelength Division Multiplexing (CWDM) supports up to 8 channels. Passive Optical Networks (PON) utilize unpowered optical splitters for connecting multiple locations. GSM and CDMA are two incompatible cellular standards used in the U.S., with GSM being more widely adopted globally. The evolution of cellular networking is outlined from 1G to 4G, with LTE offering download speeds of up to 300 Mbps. YMAX provides an alternative broadband connection using microwave transmissions, requiring line of sight, and satellite WAN connections extend networks to hard-to-reach areas but may introduce latency due to the distances involved. Additionally, Metro Ethernet and leased line WAN connections are explained, with leased lines providing dedicated circuits that can utilize protocols like Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) for multiple data transmissions.

Leased lines can utilize either plain old telephone service (POTS) or fiber optic circuits, with costs borne solely by the customer due to exclusive use. The speed of leased lines is determined by the customer's budget, and technologies like Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) allow for multiple layer 3 protocols to be transmitted simultaneously. Multiplexing technologies can increase channel capacity, with T-carrier lines in the US and E-carrier lines in Europe providing various digital signal channels (DS0, DS1, DS3) with specific bandwidths. Fiber optic connections are categorized by Optical Carrier (OC) lines, with OC rates established by SONET and SDH standards, allowing for high-speed data transmission. Circuit-switched networks maintain a dedicated path for communication, while packet-switched networks break data into packets for more efficient routing. Frame Relay and Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM) are WAN technologies that differ in packet size and efficiency, with Multi-Protocol Label Switching (MPLS) offering a scalable solution for managing network traffic across different protocols.
query: How does IPv6 address assignment and routing differ from IPv4 in terms of address types, configuration methods, and routing protocol support, and what are the implications for devices connected to a Pepwave Balance One?
answer: IPv6 address assignment differs from IPv4 by introducing new types of addresses and new methods for automatic configuration. IPv6 defines global unicast addresses (publicly routable), link-local addresses (starting with 'fe80', only for local communication), and unique local addresses (private but not internet-routable). Devices connected to a Pepwave Balance One receive both a link-local address (accessible only by devices on the same LAN port) and a global IPv6 address (accessible by any device on the LAN or internet), whereas IPv4 typically uses private addresses behind NAT. IPv6 addresses can be assigned manually, via DHCPv6, or automatically using SLAAC, which leverages router advertisements and the EUI-64 method to generate addresses. IPv6 eliminates the need for NAT for internal/external connectivity, although NAT64/NAT46 exist for interoperability. Routing in IPv6 supports both static and dynamic protocols, such as OSPFv3, with routing tables for IPv6 being independent from IPv4. OSPFv3 is configured differently, using interface assignments instead of network statements, and address families allow simultaneous support for IPv4 and IPv6. IPv6 also replaces ARP with Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP) for MAC address resolution and router discovery. The implications for Pepwave Balance One users are that devices will automatically receive both link-local and global IPv6 addresses, can participate in IPv6 routing without NAT, and benefit from improved auto-configuration and routing protocol support over IPv4.

citations.claim: IPv6 introduces address types including global unicast, link-local (fe80::/10), and unique local addresses, eliminating the need for NAT for public addressing.
On the Pepwave Balance One, the first IPv6 address is link-local (LAN only), and the second is global (LAN/internet accessible), illustrating dual address assignment.
IPv6 supports manual, DHCPv6, and SLAAC configuration, with SLAAC using router advertisements and EUI-64 for address generation.
IPv6 routing tables are independent from IPv4, and OSPFv3 supports IPv6 with interface-based configuration and address families for dual-stack operation.
IPv6 replaces ARP with Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP) for resolving MAC addresses and router discovery.

After updating the firmware on a Pepwave SOHO MK3 from version 8.0.2 to 8.1.0, the device still displays the previous firmware version after rebooting. However, the new firmware version 8.1.0 is confirmed to work perfectly on the device.

For hosting an ICVA behind a firewall, it is necessary to refer to the setup guide for the required communication ports, which may include more than just TCP ports 80 and 443.

The TCP ports 8000 and 8008 on a new Peplink Balance device are used for captive portal services. In the upcoming firmware version 8.0.1, these service ports will be disabled by default if the captive portal feature is not enabled.

Firmware version 8.0.0 on the Peplink Balance 380 is reported to work fine, provided that the device is one of the newer hardware versions. If the device is currently running version 7, it indicates that the hardware is compatible and in good condition.

Firmware version 6.1.0 has been released for the Peplink Balance 30, and further information can be found in the upgrade guide provided by Peplink.

The most recent API documentation available for Peplink devices is for firmware version 8.3.0, and there is currently no documentation released for version 8.4.0.

The NTP time server functionality for the MAX BR-1 MK2 is not available in the production code but is included in version 8.1 RC1.

To address regular outages on the MAX BR1, it is recommended to upgrade the firmware to version 7.0.2, which may resolve stability issues. The firmware can be obtained from the Peplink support downloads page, where release notes are also available for further details.

## Document_12

The USSD feature on the Pepwave Max BR1 was broken in firmware version 6.3.3 build 2252, as USSD codes enclosed in hashtags (like #123#) return an 'invalid USSD code' error, while they function correctly in firmware version 6.3.1 build 2023. Users are advised to revert to version 6.3.1 for proper functionality until the issue is resolved. There is no confirmation regarding the functionality of hashtag symbols in USSD codes with version 7 firmware, and users should be cautious about upgrading without this information.
